JavaScript in Web Browsers – II.explanation: Each Element object has style and className properties that allow scripts to specify CSS styles for a document element or to alter the CSS class names that apply to the element. The above code snippet changes the class and lets the stylesheet specify the details.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: The libraries that build a new higher-level API for client-side programming is ____________
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: Many web developers find it useful to build their web applications on top of a client side framework library. These libraries are “frameworks” in the sense that they build a new higher-level API for client-side programming on top of the standard and proprietary APIs offered by web browsers: once you adopt a framework, your code needs to be written to use the APIs defined by that framework.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: Which of the following is not a framework?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: One of the most popular frameworks is jQuery which is used in web development. Here, JavaScript is a scripting language and not a framework.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: Which of the following frameworks focuses on DOM and Ajax utilities?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: DOM stands for data object modulation. The Prototype library focuses on DOM and Ajax utilities like jQuery does, and adds quite a few core-language utilities as well.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: What is the purpose of the Dojo framework?
options: Focuses on DOM and Ajax utilities
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: The Dojo toolkit is an open-source modular toolkit containing a JavaScript library that is designed for rapidly creating JavaScript/Ajax-based websites and cross-platform applications. Dojo is a large framework that advertises its “incredible depth.” It includes an extensive set of UI widgets, a package system, a data abstraction layer, and more.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: Which is the in-house library of Yahoo!?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: YUI is the in-house library of Yahoo!, and it is used on their home page. The Yahoo User Interface Library is a discontinued open-source JavaScript library for building richly interactive web applications using techniques such as Ajax, DHTML, and DOM scripting.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: What does Dojo and YUI have in common?
options: Facilitates DOM utilities and UI Widgets
Does not facilitates DOM utilities and UI Widgets
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: Like Dojo, it is a large, all-encompassing library with language utilities, DOM utilities, UI widgets, and so on. There are actually two incompatible versions of YUI, known as YUI 2 and YUI 3.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: What are the two incompatible versions of YUI?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: YUI stands for yahoo user interface. Like Dojo, it is a large, all-encompassing library with language utilities, DOM utilities, UI widgets, and so on. There are actually two incompatible versions of YUI, known as YUI 2 and YUI 3.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: Which of the following framework was used by Google for Gmail?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: The Closure library is the client-side library that Google uses for Gmail, Google Docs, and other web applications. This library is intended to be used with the Closure compiler, which strips out unused library functions.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: Which of the following is a web application API framework?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: GWT, the Google Web Toolkit defines a web application API in Java and provides a compiler to translate your Java programs into compatible client-side JavaScript whereas Google Closure Tools is a set of tools to help developers build rich web applications with JavaScript.

JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.question: Which is more widely used than GWT in Google?
JavaScript Client-Side Frameworks.explanation: Google Closure Tools is a set of tools to help developers build rich web applications with JavaScript. GWT is used in some of Google’s products, but it is not as widely used as their Closure library.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: Which function among the following lets to register a function to be invoked once?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: setTimeout() and setInterval() allow you to register a function to be invoked once or repeatedly after a specified amount of time has elapsed. Both these function are used to do time manipulation in javascript.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: Which function among the following lets to register a function to be invoked repeatedly after a certain time?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: setTimeout() and setInterval() allow you to register a function to be invoked once or repeatedly after a specified amount of time has elapsed. Both these function are used to do time manipulation in javascript.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: Which is the handler method used to invoke when uncaught JavaScript exceptions occur?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: The onerror handler method can be registered to be invoked when uncaught JavaScript exceptions occur. The onerror event is triggered if an error occurs while loading an external file (e.g. a document or an image).

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: Which property is used to obtain browser vendor and version information?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: The navigator property is used to obtain browser vendor and version information. Various navaigator property includes appname, appversion, geolocation, language etc.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: Which method receives the return value of setInterval() to cancel future invocations?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: Like setTimeout(), setInterval() returns a value that can be passed to clearInterval() to cancel any future invocations of the scheduled function. The ID value returned by setInterval() is used as the parameter for the clearInterval() method.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: The setTimeout() belongs to which object?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: The setTimeout() method of the Window object schedules a function to run after a specified number of milliseconds elapses. setTimeout() and setInterval() are used for time manipulations in javascript.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: Which method receives the return value of setTimeout() to cancel future invocations?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: setTimeout() returns a value that can be passed to clearTimeout() to cancel the execution of the scheduled function. The ID value returned by setTimeout() is used as the parameter for the clearTimeout() method.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: What will happen if we call setTimeout() with a time of 0 ms?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: If you call setTimeout() with a time of 0 ms, the function you specify is not invoked right away. Instead, it is placed on a queue to be invoked “as soon as possible” after any currently pending event handlers finish running.

JavaScript Document Object Model.question: To which object does the location property belong?
JavaScript Document Object Model.explanation: The location property of the Window object refers to a Location object, which represents the current URL of the document displayed in the window. The window.location object can be used to get the current page address (URL) and to redirect the browser to a new page.

JavaScript Window Object.question: The URL property belongs to which of the following object?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The Document object has a URL property, which is a static string that holds the URL of the document when it was first loaded. If you want to access any element in an HTML page, you always start with accessing the document object.

JavaScript Window Object.question: What does the location property represent?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The location property of a window is a reference to a Location object; it represents the current URL of the document being displayed in that window.

JavaScript Window Object.question: Which among the following is not a property of the Location object?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The location object is part of the window object and is accessed through the window.location property. The various properties of the location object are the protocol, host, hostname, port, search, and hash.

JavaScript Window Object.question: What is the return type of the hash property?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The hash property sets or returns the anchor part of a URL. The hash property returns the “fragment identifier” portion of the URL if there is one a hash mark (#) followed by an element ID. It is accessed by using the statement location.hash.

JavaScript Window Object.question: What is the function used to extract arguments from the search property of a URL?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The urgArgs() function can be used to extract arguments from the search property of a URL. Search property can be accessed through the location object.

JavaScript Window Object.question: The decodeURIComponent() is defined by _____________
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The decodeURIComponent() is a global function defined by client-side JavaScript. The decodeURIComponent() function decodes a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) component previously created by encodeURIComponent or by a similar routine.

JavaScript Window Object.question: Which is the method that removes the current document from the browsing history before loading the new document?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The replace() removes the current document from the browsing history before loading the new document. The difference between assign method and replace(), is that replace() removes the URL of the current document from the document history, meaning that it is not possible to use the “back” button to navigate back to the original document.

JavaScript Window Object.question: Why is the replace() method better than the assign() method?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The difference between assign method and replace(), is that replace() removes the URL of the current document from the document history, meaning that it is not possible to use the “back” button to navigate back to the original document. When a script unconditionally loads a new document, the replace() method is often a better choice than assign().

JavaScript Window Object.question: What is the purpose of the assign() method?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The assign() method of the Location object makes the window load and display the document at the URL you specify. The difference between this method and replace(), is that replace() removes the URL of the current document from the document history, meaning that it is not possible to use the “back” button to navigate back to the original document.

JavaScript Window Object.question: The history property belongs to which object?
JavaScript Window Object.explanation: The history property of the Window object refers to the History object for the window. The history object is part of the window object and is accessed through the window.history property.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: What is the code snippet to go back to a history twice?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The go() method loads a specific URL from the history list. The above code snippet goes back 2, like clicking the Back button twice.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: If the window has child windows, how will the browsing histories be affected?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: If a window contains child windows, the browsing histories of the child windows are chronologically interleaved with the history of the main window. The opener property returns a reference to the window that created the window.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: The length property belongs to which of the following objects?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The length property of the History object specifies the number of elements in the browsing history list. The property returns at least 1, because the list includes the currently loaded page.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: What is the datatype of the go() method’s parameter?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The go() method takes an integer argument and can skip any number of pages forward and backward in the history list.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: What is the special feature of modern web applications?
options: Can alter contents without loading document
Must load the document to manipulate
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: Modern web applications can dynamically alter their own content without loading a new document.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: The navigator property belongs to which of the following object?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The navigator property of a Window object refers to a Navigator object that contains browser vendor and version number information. Navigator object property includes appCodeName, appVersion, appName etc.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: What is the vendor-neutral synonym for navigator?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: IE supports clientInformation as a vendor-neutral synonym for a navigator. The navigator property of a Window object refers to a Navigator object that contains browser vendor and version number information.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: Which is the preferred testing nowadays for scripting?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The “browser-sniffing” approach is problematic because it requires constant tweaking as new browsers and new versions of existing browsers are introduced. Today, feature testing is preferred rather than making assumptions about particular browser versions and their features, you simply test for the feature (i.e., the method or property) you need.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: Which of the below properties can be used for browser sniffing?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The platform and appVersion can be found out in the navigator object properties.

JavaScript Error Handling – I.question: Where is the information of the userAgent property located?
JavaScript Error Handling – I.explanation: The string that the browser sends in its USER-AGENT HTTP header. This property typically contains all the information in appVersion and may contain additional details as well.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: Each tab in the single web browser window is called as ____________
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: A single web browser window on your desktop may contain several tabs. Each tab is an independent browsing context. browser context is also defined as the environment in which the browser displays a document.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: Nested documents inside the HTML documents can be created using ___________
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: HTML documents may contain nested documents using an iframe element. An iframe creates a nested browsing context represented by a Window object of its own.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: How are windows, tabs, iframes, and frames treated according to client-side javascript?
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: Client-side JavaScript makes very little distinction between windows, tabs, iframes, and frames they are all browsing contexts, and to JavaScript, they are all Window objects.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: How are windows, tabs, iframes, and frames treated according to javascript?
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: Client-side JavaScript makes very little distinction between windows, tabs, iframes, and frames they are all browsing contexts, and to JavaScript, they are all Window objects.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: A new web browser window can be opened using which method of the Window object?
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: You can open a new web browser window with the open() method of the Window object. Window.open() loads a specified URL into a new or existing window and returns the Window object that represents that window.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: What will happen if the first argument of open() is omitted?
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: The first argument in the open function is for the url of the page which is to be opened. When the first argument of the open() is omitted, the about:blank is opened.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: Which object serves as the global object at the top of the scope chain?
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: The Window object serves as the global object at the top of the scope chain in client-side JavaScript. All global JavaScript objects, functions, and variables automatically become members of the window object.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: Which is the property of a Window object that holds the name of the frame?
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: The name property of a Window object holds the name of the frame if it has one. This property is writable, and scripts can set it as desired. An iframe creates a nested browsing context represented by a Window object of its own.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: When will the fourth argument to open() useful?
options: When the second argument names a retired window
When the first argument names an existing window
When the second argument names an existing window
When the first argument names a retired window
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: The fourth argument to open() is useful only when the second argument names an existing window. This fourth argument is a boolean value that indicates whether the URL specified as the first argument should replace the current entry in the window’s browsing history (true) or create a new entry in the window’s browsing history (false). Omitting this argument is the same as passing false.

JavaScript Error Handling – II.question: The inner frame within a top-level window can be referred to as _____________
JavaScript Error Handling – II.explanation: Frames returns the window itself, which is an array-like object, listing the direct sub-frames of the current window. If a frame is contained within another frame that is contained within a top-level window, that frame can refer to the top-level window as parent.parent.

Scripting Documents.question: The central object in a larger API is known as __________
Scripting Documents.explanation: Document Object Model (DOM) is a platform and language-neutral interface that allows programs and scripts to dynamically access and update the content, structure, and style of a document. It is the central object in a larger API, known as the Document Object Model, or DOM, for representing and manipulating document content.

Scripting Documents.question: The paragraph “p” is a part of __________
Scripting Documents.explanation: The paragraph tag belongs to both html and body tag. It is used to write paragraph on html pages.

Scripting Documents.question: The node directly above a node is called __________
Scripting Documents.explanation: The node directly above a node is the parent of that node. In HTML, the document itself is the parent node of the HTML element, HEAD and BODY are child nodes of the HTML element.

Scripting Documents.question: The Text and Comment is part of __________
Scripting Documents.explanation: The CharacterData abstract interface represents a Node object that contains characters. This is an abstract interface, meaning there aren’t any object of type CharacterData. The Text and Comment is part of the CharacterData Element.

Scripting Documents.question: The nodes that represent HTML elements are the __________
Scripting Documents.explanation: The nodes that represent HTML elements are Element nodes. The various html elements include h1, p, div etc.

Scripting Documents.question: Which of the following is/are of Text nodes?
Scripting Documents.explanation: Both Text and Comment are basically strings of text, and these nodes are much like the Text nodes that represent the displaying text of a document.

Scripting Documents.question: Which is not the way to query a document for an element or elements?
options: without the specified CSS class or classes

Scripting Documents.question: Which of the following can be used to select HTML elements based on the value of their name attributes?
Scripting Documents.explanation:
The getElementsByName() method returns a collection of all elements in the document with the specified name (the value of the name attribute), as a NodeList object.

var radiobuttons = document.getElementsByName("favorite_color");

Scripting Documents.question: Which of the following property refers to the root element of the document?
Scripting Documents.explanation: The documentElement property of the Document class refers to the root element of the document. This is always an HTML element. The documentElement property returns the documentElement of the document, as an Element object.

Scripting Documents.question: The return type of getElementsByClassName() is __________
Scripting Documents.explanation: The getElementsByClassName() method returns a collection of all elements in the document with the specified class name, as a NodeList object. The other methods of returning nodelist objects are getElementsByTagName(), getElementbyId() etc.

Scripting CSS.question: Which syntax is used to describe elements in CSS?
Scripting CSS.explanation: CSS stylesheets have a very powerful syntax, known as selectors, for describing elements or sets of elements within a document.

Scripting CSS.question: Which of the following is the ultimate element selection method?
Scripting CSS.explanation: querySelectorAll() is the ultimate element selection method: it is a very powerful technique by which client-side JavaScript programs can select the document elements that they are going to manipulate.

Scripting CSS.question: Which of the following is the Web application equivalent to querySelectorAll()?
Scripting CSS.explanation: Web applications based on jQuery use a portable, cross-browser equivalent to querySelectorAll() named $().

Scripting CSS.question: The C in CSS stands for _______________
Scripting CSS.explanation: The C in CSS stands for “cascading”. This term indicates that the style rules that apply to any given element in a document can come from a “cascade” of different sources.

Scripting CSS.question: The first version of CSS is _____________
Scripting CSS.explanation: The first version of CSS is CSS1. It was officially released in the year 1996.

Scripting CSS.question: Which of the following is not an example of a Shortcut Property?
Scripting CSS.explanation:
border, font & text are shortcut properties. For example, the font-family, font-size, font-style, and font-weight properties can all be set at once using a single font property with a compound value:

font: bold italic 24pt helvetica;

Scripting CSS.question: Which of the following is the default positioning elements with CSS?
Scripting CSS.explanation: static is the default value and specifies that the element is positioned according to the normal flow of document content (for most Western languages, this is left to right and top to bottom).

Scripting CSS.question: Which property lays the element according to the normal flow?
Scripting CSS.explanation: When the position property is set to relative, an element is laid out according to the normal flow, and its position is then adjusted relative to its position in the normal flow.

Scripting CSS.question: Which of the following property allows you to specify an element’s position with respect to the browser window?
Scripting CSS.explanation: The fixed value allows you to specify an element’s position with respect to the browser window. Elements with fixed positioning are always visible and do not scroll with the rest of the document. Like absolutely positioned elements, fixed-position elements are independent of all others and are not part of the document flow.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: The type that specifies what kind of event occurred is ____________
options: both event type and even target
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: The event type is a string that specifies what kind of event occurred. The type “mousemove”, for example, means that the user moved the mouse.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: Which is the object on which the event occurred or with which the event is associated?
options: both event type and even target
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: The event target is the object on which the event occurred or with which the event is associated. When we speak of an event, we must specify both the type and the target. The target property of the Event interface is a reference to the object that dispatched the event.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: In general, event handler is nothing but ____________
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: An event handler is in general, a function that handles or responds to an event. For example onclick, onkeypress, onload etc are event handler functions.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: When will the browser invoke the handler?
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: When an event of the specified type occurs on the specified target, the browser invokes the handler. For example onclick function is executed when mouse is clicked.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: Which property specifies the property of the event?
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: All event objects have a type property that specifies the event type. Event type is a string that specifies what kind of event occurred.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: The process by which the browser decides which objects to trigger event handlers on is ____________
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: Event propagation is the process by which the browser decides which objects to trigger event handlers. Event propagation is a way to describe the “stack” of events that are fired in a web browser.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: Which form of event propagation handles the registered container elements?
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: Event bubbling and capturing are two ways of event propagation in the HTML DOM API. With bubbling, the event is first captured and handled by the innermost element and then propagated to outer elements. With capturing, the event is first captured by the outermost element and propagated to the inner elements.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: The events that are directly tied to a specific input device are ____________
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: These are events that are directly tied to a specific input device, such as the mouse or keyboard) They include legacy event types such as “mousedown”, “mousemove”, “mouseup”, “keydown”, “keypress”, and “keyup” and also new touch specific events like “touchmove” and “gesturechange”.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: The high-level events among the following events are ____________
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: UI events are higher-level events, often on HTML form elements that define a user interface for a web application. They include the focus event (when a text input field gains keyboard focus), the change event when the user changes the value displayed by a form element, and the submit event when the user clicks a Submit button in a form.

JavaScript Events Handling.question: The events that are not directly tied to a specific input device are _____________
JavaScript Events Handling.explanation: These are input events that are not directly tied to a specific input device. The click event, for example, indicates that a link or button (or other document element) has been activated) This is often done via a mouse click, but it could also be done by keyboard or (on touch-sensitive devices) by gesture.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: The events that are not triggered directly by user activity are called ___________
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: Some events are not triggered directly by user activity, but by network or browser activity, and indicate some kind of lifecycle or state-related change. The load event, fired on the Window object when the document is fully loaded, is probably the most commonly used of these events.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: The video and the audio belong to the _________
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: The HTML5 video and audio elements define a long list of associated event types such as “waiting”, “playing”, “seeking”, “volumechange”, and so on. These events are usually only of interest to web apps that want to define custom controls for video or audio playback.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: The client-side JavaScript asynchronous programming model contains _________
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: Timers and error handlers are part of client-side JavaScript asynchronous programming model and are similar to events.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: Which are the events that have default actions that can be canceled by event handlers?
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: The submit and reset events have default actions that can be canceled by event handlers, and some click events do, too. The focus and blur events do not bubble, but all the other form events do.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: The events that represent occurrences related to the browser window are _________
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: Window events represent occurrences related to the browser window itself, rather than any specific document content displayed inside the window.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: Which event is fired when a document and all of its external resources are fully loaded and displayed to the user?
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: The load event is the most important of these events: it is fired when a document and all of its external resources (such as images) are fully loaded and displayed to the user.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: Which is the alternative to the load event?
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: DOMContentLoaded and readystatechange are alternatives to the load event: they are triggered sooner, when the document and its elements are ready to manipulate, but before external resources are fully loaded.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: Which is the opposite of the load event in JavaScript?
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: The unload event is the opposite of load: it is triggered when the user is navigating away from a document. An unload event handler might be used to save the user’s state, but it cannot be used to cancel navigation.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: Which is the property that is triggered in response to JavaScript errors?
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: The onerror property of the Window object is something like an event handler, and it is triggered in response to JavaScript errors. It isn’t a true event handler, however, because it is invoked with different arguments.

JavaScript Mouse Events.question: Which event can be fired on any scrollable document element?
JavaScript Mouse Events.explanation: Scroll events can also be fired on any scrollable document element, such as those with the CSS overflow property set.

JavaScript Text Events.question: When are the mouse events generated?
options: When user clicks the mouse over a document
When user moves over a document
When user clicks or moves the mouse over a document
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: Mouse events are generated when the user moves or clicks the mouse over a document. These events are triggered on the most deeply nested element that the mouse pointer is over, but they bubble up through the document.

JavaScript Text Events.question: The properties that specify the position and button state of the mouse are _________
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: The clientX and clientY properties specify the position of the mouse in window coordinates. The clientX property returns the horizontal coordinate (according to the client area) of the mouse pointer when a mouse event was triggered. Similarly clientY returns the vertical coordinates.

JavaScript Text Events.question: Which of the following keys are not set to true when the keyboard modifier keys are held down?
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: A modifier key is a key that modifies the action of another key when the two are pressed together. The altKey, ctrlKey, metaKey, and shiftKey properties are set to true when the corresponding keyboard modifier keys are held down.

JavaScript Text Events.question: How to detect and respond to mouse drags?
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: By registering a mousedown handler that registers a mousemove handler, you can detect and respond to mouse drags. Doing this properly involves being able to capture mouse events so that you continue to receive mousemove events even when the mouse has moved out of the element it started in.

JavaScript Text Events.question: When is the mouseover event fired?
options: When mouse is moved over a new element
When mouse is both moved and clicked
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: When the user moves the mouse so that it goes over a new element, the browser fires a mouseover event on that element. The onmouseover event occurs when the mouse pointer is moved onto an element, or onto one of its children.

JavaScript Text Events.question: When is the mouseout event fired?
options: When mouse is no longer over an element
When mouse is over an element
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: When the mouse moves so that it is no longer over an element, the browser fires a mouseout event on that element. The mouseout() method triggers the mouseout event, or attaches a function to run when a mouseout event occurs

JavaScript Text Events.question: The focus and blur events are also part of _________
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: The focus and blur events are also used as Window events: they are triggered on a window when that browser window receives or loses keyboard focus from the operating system. Focusin and onblur methods are used for using these events.

JavaScript Text Events.question: The element that can also register handlers for load and error events is _________
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: Individual document elements, such as img elements, can also register handlers for load and error events.onload and onerror methods are used for handling such events.

JavaScript Text Events.question: The events that are emulated by the jQuery library are _________
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: The jQuery library emulates focusin and focusout events for browsers that do not support them. The focusin and focusout events bubble, the focus and blur events doesn’t. That means that you can use the focusin and focusout on the parent element of a form field.

JavaScript Text Events.question: Which event is triggered sooner when the document and its elements are ready to manipulate?
JavaScript Text Events.explanation: DOMContentLoaded and readystatechange are alternatives to the load event: they are triggered sooner, when the document and its elements are ready to manipulate, but before external resources are fully loaded.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: DOM Level 3 Events standardizes which of the following events?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: The DOM Level 3 Events specification standardizes the focusin and focusout events as bubbling alternatives to the focus and blur events. The focusin and focusout events bubble, the focus and blur events doesn’t. That means that you can use the focusin and focusout on the parent element of a form field.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which of the following are the necessary events currently?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: Browsers are still allowed to generate events like DOMActivate, DOMFocusIn, and DOMNodeInserted, but these are no longer required. For example DOM activate occurs when any element becomes activate.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which object is passed as the argument to handlers for keydown, keyup, and keypress events?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: What is new in the DOM Level 3 Events specification is standardized support for two dimensional mouse wheels via the wheel event and better support for text input events with a new KeyboardEvent object that is passed as the argument to handlers for keydown, keyup, and keypress events.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which among these is a property that reports rotation of mouse wheel axes?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: A handler for a wheel event receives an event object with all the usual mouse event properties, and also deltaX, deltaY, and deltaZ properties that report rotation around three different mouse wheel axes.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which of the following property specifies the string of text that was entered?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: A textinput event handler has a data property that specifies the string of text that was entered. This data property is used for manipulating the data which is entered by the user.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which of the following is defined by the specification?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: The specification defines an inputMethod property on the event object and a set of constants representing different kinds of text input (keyboard, paste or drop, handwriting or voice recognition, and so on). prompt function is a kind of input method.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which two events will have the generated text for key events?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: For key events that generate printable characters, key and char will be equal to the generated text. Both key and char are onkeypress event which occurs when the user presses a key (on the keyboard).

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which of the following are the drag and drop events?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation:
HTML Drag and Drop interfaces enable applications to use drag and drop features in Firefox and other browsers. The API defines the following seven event types :

dragstart
drag
dragend
dragenter
dragover
dragleave
drop

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which property holds a DataTransfer object that contains information about the data being transferred and the formats in which it is available?
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: The property, dataTransfer, holds a DataTransfer object that contains information about the data being transferred and the formats in which it is available. The DataTransfer object is used to hold the data that is being dragged during a drag and drop operation.

JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.question: Which API allows scripts in a document from one server to exchange messages with scripts?
options: Both Cross-Document Messaging API & Web application API
JavaScript Drag and Drop Events.explanation: The Cross-Document Messaging API allows scripts in a document from one server to exchange messages with scripts in a document from another server. This works around the limitations of the same-origin policy in a secure way. Each message that is sent triggers a message event on the Window of the receiving document.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: When are the keyboard events fired?
options: When the user manually calls the button
When the user clicks a key
When the user calls the modifier
When the user right clicks the mouse
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: The keydown and keyup are the keyboard events are fired when the user presses or releases a key on the keyboard. They are generated for modifier keys, function keys, and alphanumeric keys.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: How does a user generate multiple keydown events?
options: Pressing the key longer than usual
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: If the user holds the key down long enough for it to begin repeating, there will be multiple keydown events before the keyup event arrives. Pressing the key for long time results in multiple calls to the function onkeypress.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which property is used to specify the key type when pressed?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: The keyCode property returns the Unicode character code of the key that triggered the onkeypress event, or the Unicode key code of the key that triggered the onkeydown or onkeyup event. The event object associated with these events has a numeric keyCode property that specifies which key was pressed.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: For what value does the keyCode property persists even when a Shift key is pressed for adding punctuation character.
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: The number keys always generate keyCode values for the digit that appears on the key, even if you are holding down Shift in order to type a punctuation character.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which of the following are not key event properties?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: altKey, ctrlKeY, shiftKey, and metaKey are key event object’s properties, which are set to true if the corresponding modifier key is held down when the event occurs. The keyCode values of ShiftKey, ctrlKey, altKey are respectively 16, 17 and 18.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which of the following key property holds the key name as a string?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: The DOM Level 3 Events defines a new key property that contains the key name as a string. Object.keys() returns an array whose elements are strings corresponding to the enumerable properties found directly upon object.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which of the following is not the value the key property will hold if the key is a function key?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: If the key is a function key, the key property will be a value like “F2”, ”F8” or ”F9”etc. The Keys from F1-F12 are known as function keys.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which method is used to add a binding?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: The bind() method creates a new function that, when called, has its this keyword set to the provided value, with a given sequence of arguments preceding any provided when the new function is called.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which method is used to remove a binding?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation: The unbind() method removes event handlers from selected elements. This method can remove all or selected event handlers, or stop specified functions from running when the event occurs.

JavaScript Keyboard Events.question: Which of the following are the parameters passed to the keymap after installation?
JavaScript Keyboard Events.explanation:
After the keymap is installed, the following parameters are passed:

The event object for the keydown event.
The key identifier of the key that was pressed.

Identifier key contains the information of the key that is pressed and the object information about the function to be performed when the key is pressed.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: How many node types are there in total?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: There are total of 12 node types. The nodeType property returns the node type, as a number, of the specified node.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: What is the purpose of the Node object property ownerDocument?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The ownerDocument property returns the owner document of a node, as a Document object. It returns the root element for a node.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: Which of the following Node object property returns the local part of the name of a node?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The Node object property localName Returns the local part of the name of a node. If the selected node is not an element or attribute, this property returns NULL.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: What is the property textContent?
options: Sets the textual content of a node
Returns the textual content of a node
Sets & Returns the textual content of a node
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The property textContent sets or returns the textual content of a node and its descendants. If you set the textContent property, any child nodes are removed and replaced by a single Text node containing the specified string.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: How many Node object methods are available?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The Node object represents a single node in the document tree. There are totally 18 node object methods.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: Which of the following Node object property returns the node immediately before a node?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The node object property previousSibling returns the node immediately before a node. The returned node is returned as a Node object.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: What is the purpose of the method getUserData(key)?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The method getUserData(key) returns the object associated to a key on a this node. The object must first have been set to this node by calling setUserData with the same key.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: How to test if two nodes are equal?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The method isEqualNode() is used to test if two nodes are equal. Two nodes are equal when they have the same type, defining characteristics (for elements, this would be their ID, number of children, and so forth), its attributes match, and so on.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: How to associate an object to a key on a node?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The Node.setUserData() method allows a user to attach (or remove) data to an element, without needing to modify the DOM. This method is used to associate an object to a key on a node.

JavaScript Node Operations – I.question: Which method is used to compare the placement of two nodes in the DOM hierarchy (document)?
JavaScript Node Operations – I.explanation: The compareDocumentPosition() method is used to compare the placement of two nodes in the DOM hierarchy (document). The return value is an integer value whose bits represent the calling Node’s relationship to otherNode within the Document.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: What does a Node object represent?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: The Node object represents a single node in the document tree. A node can be an element node, an attribute node, a text node, or any other of the node types explained in the Node Types chapter.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: What does the nodeName of the nodeType Document return?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: The nodeName of the nodeType Document returns #document. If the node is an element node, the nodeName property will return the tag name. If the node is an attribute node, the nodeName property will return the name of the attribute.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: What is the purpose of the method item()?
options: Returns node after the specified index
Returns node before the specified index
Returns the node following the specified node
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: The method item() returns the node at the specified index in a node list. The nodes are sorted as they appear in the source code, and the index starts at 0.A Node object’s collection of child nodes is an example of a NodeList object.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: How can the nodes in the node list be accessed?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: The nodes in the node list can be accessed through their index number. The nodes are sorted as they appear in the source code, and the index starts at 0.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: Which of the following is the child(s) of the node type EntityReference?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: The createEntityReference() method creates the specified EntityReference Object. The children of the node type EntityReference are Element, ProcessingInstruction, Comment, Text, CDATASection, EntityReference.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: Which node type represents the root-node of the DOM tree?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: Everything inside an html document is classified in the form of different nodes. The node type Document represents the root-node of the DOM tree, the entire document.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: What is the purpose of the DocumentFragment node type?
options: To hold a portion of a document
To split the document into fragments
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: The DocumentFragment node type represents a “lightweight” Document object that has no parent. It is used as a lightweight version of Document that stores a segment of a document structure comprised of nodes just like a standard document.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: How many nodetype – named constants are available?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: DOM nodes can be of various types, such as element nodes and text nodes, and each node has a nodeType property giving its type. There are totally 12 nodetype – named constants available.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: Which of the following Node types have a node value equal to null?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: All the three node types namely, Document, DocumentFragment, DocumentType have a node value equal to null. If the node is an element node, the nodeType property will return 1. If the node is an attribute node, the nodeType property will return 2.

JavaScript Node Operations – II.question: How many node object properties are there?
JavaScript Node Operations – II.explanation: Node interface is the primary datatype for the entire Document Object Model. The node is used to represent a single XML element in the entire document tree. There are totally 16 node object properties.

Cookies.question: Cookies were originally designed for __________
Cookies.explanation: Cookies are data, stored in small text files, on your computer. Cookies were originally designed for server-side programming, and at the lowest level, they are implemented as an extension to the HTTP protocol.

Cookies.question: The Cookie manipulation is done using which property?
Cookies.explanation: The cookie property sets or returns all name/value pairs of cookies in the current document. There are no methods involved: cookies are queried, set, and deleted by reading and writing the cookie property of the Document object using specially formatted strings.

Cookies.question: Which of the following explains Cookies nature?
Cookies.explanation: Cookies are transient by default; the values they store last for the duration of the web browser session but are lost when the user exits the browser. When a web server has sent a web page to a browser, the connection is shut down, and the server forgets everything about the user.

Cookies.question: Which attribute is used to extend the lifetime of a cookie?
Cookies.explanation: If you want a cookie to last beyond a single browsing session, you must tell the browser how long (in seconds) you would like it to retain the cookie by specifying a max-age attribute. A number of seconds until the cookie expires. A zero or negative number will expire the cookie immediately.

Cookies.question: Which of the following defines the Cookie visibility?
Cookies.explanation: sessionStorage, localStorage and Cookies all are used to store data on the client-side. Each one has its own storage and expiration limit. Cookie visibility is scoped by document origin as localStorage and sessionStorage are, and also by document path.

Cookies.question: Which of the following can be used to configure the scope of the Cookie visibility?
Cookies.explanation: The Cookie visibility scope is configurable through cookie attributes path and domain. Domain attribute in the cookie is used to specify the domain for which the cookie is sent.path includes the Path attribute in the cookie to specify the path for which this cookie is sent.

Cookies.question: How can you set a Cookie visibility scope to localStorage?
Cookies.explanation: Setting the path of a cookie to “/” gives scoping like that of localStorage and also specifies that the browser must transmit the cookie name and value to the server whenever it requests any web page on the site.

Cookies.question: Which of the following is a boolean cookie attribute?
Cookies.explanation: The final cookie attribute is a boolean attribute named secure that specifies how cookie values are transmitted over the network. By default, cookies are insecure, which means that they are transmitted over a normal, insecure HTTP connection. If a cookie is marked secure, however, it is transmitted only when the browser and server are connected via HTTPS or another secure protocol.

Cookies.question: Which of the following function is used as a consequence of not including semicolons, commas or whitespace in the Cookie value?
Cookies.explanation: Cookie values cannot include semicolons, commas, or whitespace. For this reason, you may want to use the core JavaScript global function encodeURIComponent() to encode the value before storing it in the cookie.

Cookies.question: What is the constraint on the data per cookie?
Cookies.explanation: Each cookie can hold up to only 4 KB. In practice, browsers allow many more than 300 cookies total, but the 4 KB size limit may still be enforced by some. Whereas storage of session is around a minimum of 5mb.

Scripted HTTP.question: Which property helps to initiate the HTTP requests?
Scripted HTTP.explanation: It is possible for JavaScript code to script HTTP, however. HTTP requests are initiated when a script sets the location property of a window object or calls the submit() method of a form object. The location object is part of the window object and is accessed through the window.location property.

Scripted HTTP.question: Which method is an alternative of the property location of a window object?
Scripted HTTP.explanation: HTTP requests are initiated when a script sets the location property of a window object or calls the submit() method of a form object. In both cases, the browser loads a new page.

Scripted HTTP.question: Which of the following uses scripted HTTP?
Scripted HTTP.explanation: AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScript And XML. The key feature of an Ajax application is that it uses scripted HTTP to initiate data exchange with a web server without causing pages to reload.

Scripted HTTP.question: Which of the below is a liberal reverse of Ajax?
Scripted HTTP.explanation: Comet is the reverse of Ajax: in Comet, it is the web server that initiates the communication, asynchronously sending messages to the client. The big advantage of Comet is that each client always has a communication link open to the server.

Scripted HTTP.question: The other name for Comet is _____________
Scripted HTTP.explanation: Comet is a web application model where a request is sent to the server and kept alive for a long time, until a time-out or a server event occurs. Other names for Comet include “Server Push”, “Ajax Push”, “HTTP Streaming”.

Scripted HTTP.question: Which is the element that has a src property to initiate HTTP GET request?
Scripted HTTP.explanation: Both img and script contains the src property that can be set to initiate an HTTP GET request. The src property sets or returns the value of the src attribute of an image.The required src attribute specifies the URL of an image.

Scripted HTTP.question: XMLHttpRequest is a ____________
Scripted HTTP.explanation: XMLHttpRequest is both an object and a class. The XMLHttpRequest object can be used to request data from a web server.

Scripted HTTP.question: Which of the following are the features of an HTTP request?
Scripted HTTP.explanation:
An HTTP request consists of four parts :

the HTTP request method or “verb”
the URL being requested
an optional set of request headers, which may include authentication information
an optional request body

Scripted HTTP.question: Which of the following is a feature of the HTTP response?
Scripted HTTP.explanation:
The HTTP response sent by a server has three parts :

a numeric and textual status code that indicates the success or failure of the request
a set of response headers
the response body

Scripted HTTP.question: Which is the appropriate code to begin a HTTP GET request?

jQuery Library.question: What is jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: jQuery is a fast, small, and feature-rich JavaScript library designed to simplify DOM manipulation, event handling, and animations.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is not the feature of jQuery?
options: Efficient query method for finding the set of document elements
Expressive syntax for referring to elements in the document
Useful set of methods for manipulating selected elements
Powerful functional programming techniques is not used for operating on sets of elements as a group
jQuery Library.explanation:
These features are at the heart of jQuery’s power and utility:

An expressive syntax (CSS selectors) for referring to elements in the document
An efficient query method for finding the set of document elements that match a CSS selector
A useful set of methods for manipulating selected elements
Powerful functional programming techniques for operating on sets of elements as a group, rather than one at a time
A succinct idiom (method chaining) for expressing sequences of operations.

jQuery Library.question: What is the primary advantage of using jQuery?
options: Simplifying DOM manipulation and AJAX interactions
No need for HTML or CSS knowledge
jQuery Library.explanation: jQuery simplifies DOM manipulation, event handling, animations, and AJAX interactions, making web development faster and more accessible.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is a single global function defined in the jQuery library?
jQuery Library.explanation: The jQuery library defines a single global function named jQuery(). This function is so frequently used that the library also defines the global symbol $ as a shortcut for it. The $ sign it’s just an alias to jQuery(), then an alias to a function which is used as a selector element.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is the correct way to include jQuery in an HTML document?
jQuery Library.explanation: To include jQuery in an HTML document, the correct method is to use the <script> tag with the src attribute pointing to the jQuery script file (local or hosted). This method allows the browser to load and execute the jQuery code.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is a factory function?
jQuery Library.explanation: jQuery() is a factory function rather than a constructor: it returns a newly created object but is not used with the new keyword. jQuery objects define many methods for operating on the sets of elements they represent.

jQuery Library.question: What is the purpose of the jQuery $(document).ready() function?
options: To check if the page is completely loaded
To check if the page is empty
jQuery Library.explanation: $(document).ready() is a jQuery function that runs once the DOM (Document Object Model) is fully loaded, which means that all HTML elements are available for manipulation. This ensures that your jQuery code doesn’t run before the page is ready, preventing errors.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is a heavily overloaded function?
jQuery Library.explanation: $() is just an alias function of jquery(). The jQuery() function (a.k.a) $()) is the most important one in the jQuery library. It is heavily overloaded, however, and there are four different ways you can invoke it.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is a utility function in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: jQuery.noConflict() is the utility function in jQuery. The noConflict() method releases the hold on the $ shortcut identifier, so that other scripts can use it.

jQuery Library.question: Which method is used to retrieve the value of an input field in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .val() method in jQuery is used to retrieve the value of form input fields (like text boxes, radio buttons, checkboxes, etc.). It can also be used to set the value.

jQuery Library.question: How can you remove an element from the DOM using jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .remove() method in jQuery is used to completely remove the selected element from the DOM. The .detach() method works similarly but keeps the data and events attached to the element, which can be useful for re-insertion later.

jQuery Library.question: How do you bind multiple events to a single element in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .on() method in jQuery is highly versatile and can bind multiple events to an HTML element, such as click, hover, focus, and more.

jQuery Library.question: Which jQuery method is used to add content at the end of an HTML element?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .append() method is used to add content at the end of an HTML element.

jQuery Library.question: Which is the method that operates on the return value of $()?
jQuery Library.explanation: The css() method sets or returns one or more style properties for the selected elements. The css() method operates on the jQuery object returned by $(), and returns that same object, so that the show() method can be invoked next in a compact “method chain.”

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is an equivalent replacement of $(document).ready(f)?
jQuery Library.explanation: The equivalent replacement of $(document).ready(f) is $(f). Writing $(document) performs the function of selecting the whole document which is the same as writing $() only.

jQuery Library.question: Which method is commonly used to send an AJAX GET request in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .get() method sends an AJAX GET request to the server and returns data.

jQuery Library.question: Which method allows you to dynamically change an element’s CSS properties in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .css() method in jQuery allows you to get or set CSS properties of HTML elements.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is used for parsing JSON text?
jQuery Library.explanation: jQuery.parseJSON() is used for parsing JSON text. The function converts json to javascript object.

jQuery Library.question: What does the $(this).css() method do?
options: Changes the entire CSS of the page
Changes the background color of the page
Retrieves the current CSS of the page
Changes the CSS of the selected element
jQuery Library.explanation: $(this).css() is used to get or set CSS properties of the element referenced by this. It is commonly used in event handlers to modify the appearance of the specific element being interacted with.

jQuery Library.question: Which method in jQuery is used to find the closest parent element matching a selector?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .closest() method in jQuery traverses up the DOM tree and finds the nearest ancestor element that matches a specified selector.

jQuery Library.question: Why would you use jQuery instead of plain JavaScript?
options: Simplified syntax for DOM manipulation and AJAX calls
jQuery Library.explanation: jQuery offers browser compatibility, a simplified syntax for DOM manipulation, easy AJAX integration, and built-in animation and effects, which make web development faster and more efficient.

jQuery Library.question: Which method attaches a click event to an HTML button element?
jQuery Library.explanation: In jQuery, the .click() method is the most commonly used way to attach a click event handler. It listens for a click and executes a specified function.

jQuery Library.question: How do you handle errors in an AJAX call in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .fail() method in jQuery is used to handle errors in AJAX calls, allowing you to debug issues, display error messages, and ensure a better user experience.

jQuery Library.question: Which jQuery selector would you use to select all elements with the class highlight?
jQuery Library.explanation: The $(“.highlight”) selector in jQuery selects all HTML elements that have the class highlight.

jQuery Library.question: How do you remove all child elements from a selected element in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .empty() method removes all child elements and content from the selected element. It leaves the element itself in place, but with no children or inner content.

jQuery Library.question: What does the jQuery $.ajax() function do?
options: Makes a request to the database
Makes a request to the server and returns the result synchronously
jQuery Library.explanation: The $.ajax() function in jQuery is used to perform asynchronous HTTP requests (AJAX). It allows you to fetch data from a server without refreshing the page. The response is handled using callback functions.

jQuery Library.question: What does the .wrap() method in jQuery do?
options: Wraps the selected element with a new div
Wraps the selected element inside a modal window
Wraps the selected element in another element
Adds content to the selected element
jQuery Library.explanation: The .wrap() method in jQuery wraps the selected elements inside a new HTML element. This is useful for applying a structure or style to a group of elements.

jQuery Library.question: Which symbol is used to select a class in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: In jQuery, the period (.) symbol is used to select elements by class. For example, $(“.class-name”) will select all elements with the class “class-name”.

jQuery Library.question: Which jQuery method creates a fade-in effect?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .fadeIn() method creates a smooth fade-in effect by gradually changing the opacity of an element from 0 to 1, making it appear on the page.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following is used to load an external HTML file into a specified HTML element using jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .load() method in jQuery allows you to load an external HTML file into a specified element on the page, making it easier to dynamically update content.

jQuery Library.question: What does the jQuery selector $(“div p”) do?
options: Selects all <div> elements with a p class
jQuery Library.explanation:
The selector $(“div p”) selects all

elements that are descendants of

elements, regardless of their level in the hierarchy.

jQuery Library.question: What does the jQuery method .each() do?
options: Adds a new class to elements
jQuery Library.explanation: The .each() method in jQuery allows you to iterate over each selected element and apply a function to each one, making it useful for performing actions on multiple elements.

jQuery Library.question: Which of the following events does jQuery not support?
jQuery Library.explanation: While jQuery supports a wide range of events, .dblclick() is not one of them. However, jQuery provides the .click() event to handle click events.

jQuery Library.question: How do you trigger an event manually in jQuery?
jQuery Library.explanation: The .trigger() method in jQuery is used to manually trigger an event on an element, allowing you to simulate an event without requiring user interaction.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: The main purpose of JavaScript in web browser is to ___________
options: Creating animations and other visual effects
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation:
JavaScript can help to facilitate that experience, for example by:

Creating animations and other visual effects to subtly guide a user and help with page navigation
Sorting the columns of a table to make it easier for a user to find what she needs

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: A JavaScript program can traverse and manipulate document content through __________
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: A JavaScript program can traverse and manipulate document content through the Document object and the Element objects it contains. It can alter the presentation of that content by scripting CSS styles and classes. The Element object represents an HTML element, like P, DIV, A, TABLE, or any other HTML element.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: The behaviour of the document elements can be defined by __________
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: The JavaScript program can define the behavior of document elements by registering appropriate event handlers. A JavaScript program can traverse and manipulate document content through the Document object and the Element objects it contains.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: The service(s) that enables networking through scripted HTTP requests is __________
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: The best known advanced services is the XMLHttpRequest object, which enables networking through scripted HTTP requests. The XMLHttpRequest object can be used to request data from a web server.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: The HTML5 specification does not includes __________
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: The HTML5 specification (which, at the time of this writing, is still in draft form) and related specifications are defining a number of other important APIs for web apps. These include data storage and graphics APIs.The data storage api can store data locally within the user’s browser.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: Which of the following is not an advanced services?
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: Data storage is used to store data locally on user’s computer and networking is used for connecting between different platforms.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: JavaScript code between a pair of “script” tags are called __________
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: The <script> tag is used to define a client-side script (JavaScript). The <script> element either contains scripting statements, or it points to an external script file through the src attribute. Inline code are those that are written between a pair of “script” tags.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: Client-side JavaScript code is embedded within HTML documents in __________
options: A URL that uses the special javascript:encoding
A URL that uses the special javascript:stack
A URL that uses the special javascript:protocol
A URL that uses the special javascript:code
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation:
The Client-side JavaScript code is embedded within HTML documents in four ways :

Inline, between a pair of “script” tags
From an external file specified by the src attribute of a “script” tag
In an HTML event handler attribute, such as onclick or onmouseover
In a URL that uses the special javascript: protocol.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: What is the programming philosophy that argues that content and behaviour should as much as possible be kept separate?
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: A programming philosophy known as unobtrusive JavaScript argues that content (HTML) and behavior (JavaScript code) should as much as possible be kept separate. According to this programming philosophy, JavaScript is best embedded in HTML documents using “script” elements with src attributes.

JavaScript Client-Side Databases.question: Which of the following communicates with server-side CGI scripts through HTML form submissions and can be written without the use of JavaScript?
JavaScript Client-Side Databases.explanation: An interactive web page can dynamically vary its content based on user preferences. Interactive web pages that communicate with server-side CGI scripts through HTML form submissions were the original “web application” and can be written without the use of JavaScript.

Scripted Media.question: What is the advantage of the code produced graphics being smaller than the images themselves?
Scripted Media.explanation: The code used to produce graphics on the client side is typically much smaller than the images themselves, creating substantial bandwidth savings.

Scripted Media.question: Which of the following uses a lot of CPU cycles?
Scripted Media.explanation: Dynamic graphics for data, means simulating motion or movement using the computer. It may also be thought of as multiple plots linked by time. Dynamically generating graphics from real-time data uses a lot of CPU cycles.

Scripted Media.question: Which HTML element is used to include images?
Scripted Media.explanation: Web pages include images using the HTML img element. src tag is used to include the image link.

Scripted Media.question: What is the purpose of image replacement?
Scripted Media.explanation: Image replacement is a technique developed to allow designers to use image-based typesetting while meeting accessibility requirements. One common use for image replacement is to implement image rollovers, in which an image changes when the mouse pointer moves over it.

Scripted Media.question: When is JavaScript called obtrusive?
Scripted Media.explanation: When the amount of JavaScript code is so large that it effectively obscures the HTML, we call JavaScript as obtrusive. On the other hand unobtrusive JavaScript is a best practice methodology for attaching JavaScript to the front-end of a website.

Scripted Media.question: Which is a possible way of finding all the img elements in the document?
Scripted Media.explanation: The best suited option is document.image[] to find all img elements in the document.[index] is used to specify the index of which img tag is to be selected.

Scripted Media.question: Which of the following elements are used to include audio?
Scripted Media.explanation: The audio tag is used to include audio in the HTML document. The audio tag includes method like play(), pause() etc.

Scripted Media.question: Which of the following attributes are common to both audio and video?
Scripted Media.explanation: Both audio and video support a controls attribute. When present, it specifies that audio controls should be displayed. Both audio and video support a controls attribute.

Scripted Media.question: Which of the following is not the property of the video tag?
Scripted Media.explanation: The video tag does not contain a breadth property. The width and height property specifies the width and height of the video.

Scripted Media.question: Which of the following is the parameter used to invoke the Audio() constructor?
Scripted Media.explanation: The HTMLAudioElement interface provides access to the properties of <audio> elements, as well as methods to manipulate them. It derives from the HTMLMediaElement interface. The parameter type of the Audio() constructor is any file type that contains audio to be played.

JavaScript Graphics.question: What is the purpose of the canvas element?
options: Exposes powerful drawing API to client-side JavaScript
Creates drawing surface & Exposes powerful drawing API to client-side JavaScript
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The HTML canvas element is used to draw graphics, on the fly, via JavaScript. The canvas element is only a container for graphics. The canvas element has no appearance of its own but creates a drawing surface within the document and exposes a powerful drawing API to client-side JavaScript.

JavaScript Graphics.question: From which version of IE is canvas supported?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The canvas element is not supported by IE before IE9, but it can be reasonably well emulated in IE6, 7, and 8. It is supported from version 4 in chrome and 2 in firefox.

JavaScript Graphics.question: Which method is used to obtain the “drawing context” object?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The HTMLCanvasElement.getContext() method returns a drawing context on the canvas, or null if the context identifier is not supported. Most of the Canvas drawing API is defined not on the canvas element itself, but instead on a “drawing context” object obtained with the getContext() method of the canvas.

JavaScript Graphics.question: What is the returning value of the getContext() method?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: Call getContext() with the argument “2d” to obtain a CanvasRenderingContext2D object that you can use to draw two-dimensional graphics into the canvas. It is important to understand that the canvas element and its context object are two very different objects.

JavaScript Graphics.question: How does SVG describe complex shapes?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: SVG stands for ‘Scalable Vector Graphics’ and it is used to define graphics for the Web. SVG is mostly used for vector type diagrams like Two-dimensional graphs in an X, Y coordinate system, Pie charts etc. SVG describes complex shapes as a “path” of lines and curves that can be drawn or filled.

JavaScript Graphics.question: Which is the method invoked to begin a path?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The beginPath() method begins a path, or resets the current path. It is called before creating any path or curve.

JavaScript Graphics.question: Which is the method invoked to connect the last vertex back to the first?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The closePath() method connects the last vertex back to the first, thereby creating a path. It connects the last point to the first point thereby creating a closed figure.

JavaScript Graphics.question: Which of the following are not the properties of a canvas object?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The fillStyle property sets or returns the color, gradient, or pattern used to fill the drawing. The strokeStyle property sets or returns the color, gradient, or pattern used for strokes. There is no property called lineSize associated with the canvas object.

JavaScript Graphics.question: Which of the following is a property used to check how crisp or fuzzy shadows are?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: shadowBlur is used to check how crisp or fuzzy shadows are. The shadowBlur property sets or returns the blur level for shadows.

JavaScript Graphics.question: How do you restore a saved coordinate system?
JavaScript Graphics.explanation: The saved coordinate system is restored by calling the method restore() associated with the canvas object. The restore() method reset the canvas by “popping” the last state saved to the stack.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: What is the purpose of a Rendering Engine?
options: Both Parsing & Drawing all objects in page
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: It’s responsible for displaying the web page. The rendering engine parses the HTML and the CSS and displays the parsed content on the screen. A Rendering Engine is generally used for parsing and drawing all of the objects in the page.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: What is the purpose of the JavaScript Engine?
