Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The JavaScript Engine is generally used for interpreting the JavaScript. It is used to interpret the javascript and execute the javscript on the web page.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which layer is used to handle the HTTP requests?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: HTTP is a protocol which allows the fetching of resources, such as HTML documents. It is the foundation of any data exchange on the Web and a client-server protocol, which means requests are initiated by the recipient, usually the Web browser. The network layer is used to handle the HTTP requests.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: The User Interface is taken care of which layer?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The user interface layer represents the front end of the Web Client, and contains the actual GUI elements that users view and click. The UI Layer takes care of the User Interface.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which of the following browsers use Webkit?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: WebKit is a browser engine used in Apple’s Safari browser and other products. Webkit is what Chrome and Safari use, and is your target for most mobile web development since it is used as the layout or rendering engine for Android devices as well as mobile Safari for iOS devices and the Silk browser on Kindle Fires.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which of the following first developed Gecko?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: Gecko is the name of the layout engine developed by the Mozilla Project. Gecko was first developed at Netscape, before the Mozilla Project spun out as its own entity, as the successor to the original Netscape rendering engine, back in 1997.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which of the following render HTML?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: Rendering Engine takes HTML code and interprets it into what you see visually. More tools than just browsers render HTML, including email clients and web components in other applications.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: SpiderMonkey was developed by _____________
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: SpiderMonkey is Mozilla’s JavaScript engine written in C and C++. It is used in various Mozilla products, including Firefox, and is available under the MPL2. SpiderMonkey is the JavaScript engine made by Mozilla that is used in Firefox.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Carakan is used by which of the following browsers?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: Opera uses Carakan, which was introduced in 2010. Mozilla uses spidermonkey and safari uses nitro javascript engine.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 1
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which is the alternate name for JavaScriptCore that is used by Safari?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: Safari uses JavaScriptCore, sometimes called Nitro. Opera uses Carakan and Mozilla uses SpiderMonkey.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: What are the features of an interpreter?
options: Shared with other properties & Embedded in other tools
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: A JavaScript engine is a program or an interpreter which executes JavaScript code. The interpreter can be shared with other properties, or embedded in other tools.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Why is the total size of the page important?
options: Size of IP packet should be less than 65500
Size of IP packet should be less than 65535
Size of IP packet should be greater than 65500
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The total size of the page is important, not just because of the time it takes to download, but because the maximum size of an IP packet is 65535 octets for IPv4 and IPv6.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: How will the HTTP GET request be sent from the browser?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The two most common methods of http are get and post. Once the TCP/IP connection has been established, the browser sends an HTTP GET request over the connection to the remote server. The remote server finds the resource and returns it in an HTTP Response, the status of which is 200 to indicate a good response.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: What is the return type of the remote server?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The remote server finds the resource and returns it in an HTTP Response, the status of which is 200 to indicate a good response. 400 status code is used to indicate a bad request.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which layer is used to control the communication between the hardware in the network?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The Network Access Layer is the lowest layer of the TCP/IP protocol hierarchy. The Network Access layer controls the communication between the hardware in the network.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which layer is used to handle the network addressing and routing?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The internet layer is a group of internetworking methods, protocols, and specifications in the Internet protocol suite that are used to transport network packets from the originating host across network boundaries. The Internet layer handles network addressing and routing, getting IP and MAC addresses.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: The layer in which the TCP (or UDP) communication takes place is _____________
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: The transport layer is the layer in the open system interconnection (OSI) model responsible for end-to-end communication over a network. The Transport layer is where our TCP (or UDP) communication takes place.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Which layer handles top-level communication?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: An application layer is an abstraction layer that specifies the shared communications protocols and interface methods used by hosts in a communications network. The Application layer handles the top-level communication that the client and servers use, like HTTP and SMTP for email clients.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: What are the various possessions in the three-way handshake by the TCP?
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: TCP stands for transmission control protocol which controls the transmission of data over the internet. This handshake consists of a Synchronize, Synchronize-Acknowledge, and Acknowledge message to be passed between the browser and the remote server. This handshake allows the client to attempt communication, the server to acknowledge and accept the attempt, and the client to acknowledge that the attempt has been accepted.

Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.topic: Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScript – 2
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.question: Arrange the TCP/IP model layers in the order from farthest to closest to the end user.
options: Network Access Layer, Internet Layer, Application Layer, Transport Layer
Network Access Layer, Transport Layer, Internet Layer, Application Layer
Network Access Layer, Internet Layer, Transport Layer, Application Layer
Network Access Layer, Application Layer, Internet Layer, Transport Layer
Browser Parsing and Rendering in JavaScr.explanation: TCP stands for Transmission Control Protocol. The TCP/IP model is a concise version of the OSI model. The four layers in the TCP/IP model are, in order from farthest to closest to the end user, the Network Access layer, the Internet layer, the Transport layer, and the Application layer.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: How do we define the term Thread?
options: Device that controls input & Variable that controls movement
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: Threads are sequential units of controlled execution for applications. A thread of execution is the smallest sequence of programmed instructions that can be managed independently by a scheduler, which is typically a part of the operating system.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What does the browser do to set up a TCP/IP connection?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: A three-way handshake is a method used in a TCP/IP network to create a connection between a local host/client and server. It is a three-step method that requires both the client and server to exchange SYN and ACK (acknowledgment) packets before actual data communication begins.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What does the handshake pass between the browser and the remote server?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: A three-way handshake is a method used in a TCP/IP network to create a connection between a local host/client and server. The handshake consists of a Synchronize, Synchronize-Acknowledge, and Acknowledge message to be passed between the browser and the remote server.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: How does the handshake help the server?
options: Both Acknowledge and Accept the attempt
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: The handshake allows the server to acknowledge and accept the attempt. The handshake consists of a Synchronize, Synchronize-Acknowledge, and Acknowledge message to be passed between the browser and the remote server.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What is the purpose of the transport layer?
options: Both TCP and UDP Communication takes place
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: The transport layer is the layer in the open system interconnection (OSI) model responsible for end-to-end communication over a network. The Transport layer is where our TCP (or UDP) communication takes place.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What does the status code 200 indicate?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: The status code 200 indicates a successful response from the server. A 400 status code represents a bad request.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What does the status code 500 indicate?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: The 500 status code, or Internal Server Error, means that server cannot process the request for an unknown reason. Sometimes this code will appear when more specific 5xx errors are more appropriate.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What does the application layer handle?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: An application layer is an abstraction layer that specifies the shared communications protocols and interface methods used by hosts in a communications network. The Application layer handles the top-level communication that the client and servers use, like HTTP and SMTP for email clients.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: Which status code indicates that the server could not find the resource requested?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: The HTTP 404, 404 Not Found, and 404 error message is a Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) standard response code, in computer network communications, to indicate that the client was able to communicate with a given server, but the server could not find what was requested.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.question: What is the maximum size of an IP packet for IPv4 or IPv6?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 1.explanation: Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) is the fourth version of the Internet Protocol (IP). IPv6 is the most recent version of Internet Protocol. The maximum size of an IP packet for IPv4 or IPv6 is 65535.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: How can we define the term Performance?
options: Speed of the input takes in
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: Performance refers to the speed at which an application functions. It is a multifaceted aspect of quality. Better performance results in better user experience.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: When is an application said to show a web performance?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: Web performance refers to the speed in which web pages are downloaded and displayed on the user’s web browser. When we’re talking about web applications, the time it takes your application to be presented to your users is what we will call web performance.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: When is an application said to show a runtime performance?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: The speed at which your application responds to your users’ interactions is what we’ll call runtime performance. Better runtime performance results in better user experience.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: What does the span of time waiting for the page to be useful depending on?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: Web performance refers to the speed in which web pages are downloaded and displayed on the user’s web browser. The span of time that you are waiting for the page to be usable depends on web performance.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: What is the advantage of the code produced graphics being smaller than the images themselves?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: The code used to produce graphics on the client side is typically much smaller than the images themselves, creating substantial bandwidth savings. This also helps in increasing web performance.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: In order to skip or seek to the desired location in a sound or video, which property becomes helpful?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: The currentTime property sets or returns the current position (in seconds) of the audio/video playback. In addition to starting and stopping sound and video, you can skip (or “seek”) to the desired location within the media by setting the currentTime property.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: Which of the following shows a better runtime performance for coalescing functionality, using functions, and using objects?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: When we compare the runtime performance for coalescing functionality, using functions, and using objects, the Firefox UsingFunct shows better performance. UsingFunct improves runtime performance and inturn the user experience.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: Which of the following shows a poorer runtime performance for coalescing functionality, using functions, and using objects?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: When we compare the runtime performance for coalescing functionality, using functions, and using objects, the Firefox UsingFunct shows a poorer performance. This results in poor user experience.

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: In how many modes can the Closure compiler be run?
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation:
Closure Compiler can be run in either of two modes:

In Simple mode it mostly performs like most other minifiers, removing whitespace, line breaks, and comments
In Advanced mode it rewrites the JavaScript by renaming variables and functions from longer descriptive names to single letters to save file size, and it inlines functions, coalescing them into single functions wherever it determines that it can

JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.question: What is the purpose of the advanced mode in the Closure compiler?
options: Removing the variables and other parameters
Renaming the variables and other parameters
Slight alteration to improve the runtime performance
JavaScript Performance Measures – 2.explanation: In Advanced mode, the Closure Compiler rewrites the JavaScript by renaming variables and functions from longer descriptive names to single letters to save file size, and it inlines functions, coalescing them into single functions wherever it determines that it can.

JavaScript with FireBug.question: Firebug is an extension of which browser?
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation: Firebug is a discontinued free and open-source web browser extension for Mozilla Firefox that facilitated the live debugging, editing, and monitoring of any website’s CSS, HTML, DOM, XHR, and JavaScript.

JavaScript with FireBug.question: Firebug can be used to inspect ___________
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation: Firebug is an extension for the Mozilla Firefox browser that allows you to debug and inspect HTML, CSS, the Document Object Model (DOM) and JavaScript. In addition to debugging web pages, Firebug was used for web security testing and web page performance analysis.

JavaScript with FireBug.question: Why do Web Developers use Firebug?
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation:
Web developers use Firebug for the following reasons:

Inspect the behavior of HTML/CSS, and modify style & layout with true WYSIWYG
Debug JavaScript
Detect performance of website
Track Cookies & Sessions
Web security analysis

JavaScript with FireBug.question: What are the goals for using Firebug?
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation:
The goals for using Firebug is:

Performance
Modularity
Shared code
Compatibility
Web security analysis

JavaScript with FireBug.question: Which of the following is not a feature of the User Interface?
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation:
The features present in the User Interface are:

Port of Firebug’s Visual Object Representation (aka Reps)
Recreation of Firebug 1.3 User Interface with pixel precision
Menu options
Resizable Side Panel
Skinnable Interface

JavaScript with FireBug.question: What is the default value of the property overrideConsole?
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation: The default value of the property overrideConsole is true.

JavaScript with FireBug.question: Which of the following property(s) has a default value as false?
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation: Only disableXHRListener property has a default value false. The properties disableWhenFirebugActive and showIconWhenHidden has a default value of true.

JavaScript with FireBug.question: Which of the following action is possible in Firebug when used as a JavaScript Debugger and Profiler?
options: Find Scripts easily & also Pause execution in any line
JavaScript with FireBug.explanation: When Firebug is used as a JavaScript Debugger and Profiler, it can be used to find scripts easily and also pause the execution in any desired line. Thus it helps in debugging javascript much easier.

JavaScript with FireBug.question: The let keyword can be used ___________
options: in a for or for/in loop, as a substitute for var
as a block statement, to define new variables
to define variables that are scoped to a single expression

JavaScript with YSlow.question: How does PhantonJS use YSlow?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: YSlow for PhantomJS is a command line script that allows page performance analysis from live URLs, unlike YSlow for Command Line (HAR) where a pre-generated HAR file is needed in order to analyze page performance.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: What are the two output formats YSlow uses?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: YSlow for PhantomJS is a command line script that allows page performance analysis from live URLs. YSlow for PhantomJS introduces new output formats for automated test frameworks: TAP (Test Anything Protocol) and JUnit.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: Initially, YSlow was an extension of which browser?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: Initially, YSlow was an extension of Firefox. YSlow for Firefox needs Firebug to run.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: Which of the following can be used for a deeper analysis of the web page’s performance?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: YSlow analyzes web page performance by examining all the components on the page, including components dynamically created by using JavaScript. It measures the page’s performance and offers suggestions for improvement.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: How many rules are there in the YSlow version 2.0?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation:
There are totally 23 rules in the ruleset of YSlow (V2) namely :

Minimize HTTP Requests
Use a Content Delivery Network
Avoid empty src or href
Add an Expires or a Cache-Control Header
Gzip Components
Put StyleSheets at the Top
Put Scripts at the Bottom
Avoid CSS Expressions
Make JavaScript and CSS External
Reduce DNS Lookups
Minify JavaScript and CSS
Avoid Redirects
Remove Duplicate Scripts
Configure ETags
Make AJAX Cacheable
Use GET for AJAX Requests
Reduce the Number of DOM Elements
No 404s
Reduce Cookie Size
Use Cookie-Free Domains for Components
Avoid Filters
Do Not Scale Images in HTML
Make favicon.ico Small and Cacheable

JavaScript with YSlow.question: Which of the following is mandatory to run before running YSlow?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: YSlow analyzes web page performance by examining all the components on the page, including components dynamically created by using JavaScript. It is mandatory to run FireBug before running YSlow.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: How does the YSlow for Mobile work as?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: The YSlow for Mobile works as bookmaklet. Bookmarklet is a JavaScript code stored as the URL of a bookmark in a web browser.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: Which network allows you to distribute static assets like images, etc?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: A content delivery network (CDN) allows you to distribute your static assets like images, JavaScript files and stylesheets to geographically distributed servers. This gets the content of your page to your user’s browser faster.

JavaScript with YSlow.question: What are the three important manipulations done in a for loop on a loop variable?
JavaScript with YSlow.explanation: In a for loop, the initialization, the test, and the update are the three crucial manipulations of a loop variable. Firstly the variable is created then it’s first tested then updated.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: When does WebPageTest become necessary?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: If you want to run tests on web sites that are not publicly available—like a QA or development environment, or if you can only have your test results stored on your own servers because of legal or other reasons, then installing your own private instance of WebPagetest is the way to go.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: What is the purpose of the Auth tab in the testing platform?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: In the Auth tab you can specify credentials to use if the web site uses HTTP authentication for access.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: What is the purpose of the Script tab?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: The Script tab can be used to run more complex tests that involve multiple steps including navigate to multiple URLs, etc.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: Which is the command that is used to spoof the client user agent?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: The setUserAgent spoofs the client user agent.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: What is the purpose of the Block tab?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: The Block tab allows us to block content coming in our request.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: What is the purpose of the Video tab?
options: To take video of the page
To capture screenshots of the test only
To take video of the test
To capture screenshots of the page
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: The Video tab allows you to capture screenshots of your page as it loads and views them as a video.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: What is the task of the Advanced Panel?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: In the Advanced panel, you can have the test stop running at document completion. That will tell us when the document.onload event is fired, instead of when all assets on the page are loaded.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: What is the vulnerability of XHR communications?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: XMLHttpRequest (XHR) is an API in the form of an object whose methods transfer data between a web browser and a web server. XHR communications that may happen after page load could register as new activity and skew the test results.

JavaScript with WebPagetest.question: Which of the following methods adds and connects the point to the cubic bezier curve?
JavaScript with WebPagetest.explanation: A cubic bezier curve requires three points. The first two points are control points that are used in the cubic Bézier calculation and the last point is the ending point for the curve. Web Sockets in JavaScript.question: Which of the following is a stateless protocol?

Web Sockets in JavaScript.question: What does the value 2 of the WebSocket attribute Socket.readyState indicate?

A value of 0 indicates that the connection has not yet been established.
A value of 1 indicates that the connection is established and communication is possible.
A value of 2 indicates that the connection is going through the closing handshake.
A value of 3 indicates that the connection has been closed or could not be opened.
