Integrating the Performance JavaScript O.question: Which of the following property is associated with the Request event?
Integrating the Performance JavaScript O.explanation: The Request event has only one property: requestStart. The Request event has only one property: requestStart.

Integrating the Performance JavaScript O.topic: Integrating the Performance JavaScript Object with PerfLogger
Integrating the Performance JavaScript O.question: Which of the following API can be used to get the timing without affecting the page loading process?
Integrating the Performance JavaScript O.explanation: The Navigation Timing API provides data that can be used to measure the performance of a web site. The timing code is on the page, so it affects how the page loads and the time that takes. The Navigation Timing API can be used to get the timing without affecting the page loading process.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: How many read-only attributes are present in the navigator object?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation:
The navigator object contains information about the browser. There are a total of 2 read-only attributes present in the navigator object namely:

redirectCount
type.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Why are HTTP redirects significant?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: HTTP redirects are significant because they cause a complete roundtrip for each redirect. The original request is returned from the web server as either a 301 or a 302 with the path to the new location.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Where does the DNS reply go to in a single HTTP redirect?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: DNS is a query/response protocol. The client queries information (for example the IP address corresponding to www.google.com) in a single UDP request. The DNS reply goes to the Browser in a single HTTP redirect.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: How can one access the redirectCount property?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: The redirectCount property can be accessed as performance.navigation.redirectCount. The PerformanceNavigation.redirectCount read-only property returns an unsigned short representing the number of REDIRECTs done before reaching the page.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: How many constant values can the property type be represented?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: The type property sets or returns the value of the type attribute of an <object> element. The type attribute specifies the Internet media type (formerly known as MIME type) of the object. Totally 4 constant values can be represented by the property type.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Which of the following constants has the value 255?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: TYPE_BACK_FORWARD performs navigation through a history traversal operation. TYPE_RESERVED Has the value of 255 and is a catch-all for any navigation type not defined above.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What is the purpose of the constant TYPE_RELOAD?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: TYPE_RELOAD: Has the value of 1, indicating that the current page was arrived at via a reload operation. TYPE_RELOAD performs navigation through the reload operation or the location.reload() method.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What does the constant TYPE_BACK_FORWRD indicate?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: TYPE_BACK_FORWARD performs navigation through a history traversal operation. TYPE_BACK_FORWARD Has the value of 2, indicating that the page was navigated to via the browser history, either using the back or forward buttons or programmatically through the browser’s history object.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Which of the following constants hold the value 2?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: TYPE_BACK_FORWARD performs navigation through a history traversal operation. TYPE_BACK_FORWARD: Has the value of 2, indicating that the page was navigated to via the browser history, either using the back or forward buttons or programmatically through the browser’s history object.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Where does the DNS Lookup direct to ?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: DNS is a query/response protocol. The client queries an information (for example the IP address corresponding to www.google.com) in a single UDP request. The DNS Lookup directs to the DNS Server.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: How many properties are available in a memory object?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation:
Advanced JavaScript application features such as caches and undo buffers need to know the memory consumption of objects in order to function effectively. There are a total of 3 memory objects namely:

jsHeapSizeLimit
totalJsHeapSize
usedJsHeapSize.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What is a heap in JavaScript?
options: Collection of data stored in memory
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: A heap is a tree-like data structure where each node must be ordered with respect to the value of its children. The heap is the collection of JavaScript objects that the interpreter keeps in resident memory.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What is the function of the memory object?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: The JavaScript Memory column represents the JS heap. This column contains two values. The value you’re interested in is the live number (the number in parentheses). The memory object is a feature of Chrome that allows us to see the memory usage that Chrome is taking up while running our page.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What is the command to access the Heap size limit?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: Memory contains an object created with MemoryInfo constructor, containing jsHeapSizeLimit, totalJSHeapSize and usedJSHeapSize properties with numerical values. The command performance.memory. jsHeapSizeLimit is used to access the Heap size limit.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What is the purpose of garbage collection?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: When the interpreter sees an object in the heap with no object references, it removes that object from the heap. This is called garbage collection. An object is considered garbage collectible if there are zero references pointing at this object.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What does the usedJsHeapSize property indicate?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: usedJsHeapSize returns an object of type ObjectObject. An object created with MemoryInfo constructor, containing jsHeapSizeLimit, totalJSHeapSize and usedJSHeapSize properties with numerical values. The usedJsHeapSize property is the amount of memory that all of the current objects in the heap are using.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Which of the following property indicate the total size of the heap?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: usedJsHeapSize stores an object created with MemoryInfo constructor, containing jsHeapSizeLimit, totalJSHeapSize and usedJSHeapSize properties with numerical values.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: What can be done to monitor the memory usage?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: Garbage collected languages help developers manage memory by periodically checking which previously allocated pieces of memory can still be “reached” from other parts of the application. Profiling allows us to monitor our memory usage.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Which of the following gives the high level breakdown of memory usage?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: The Memory column represents native memory. DOM nodes are stored in native memory. If this value is increasing, DOM nodes are getting created. Typing about:memory into the location bar brings up a page that gives a high-level breakdown of memory usage.

JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.question: Which keyword must be used to get a more granular insight into the memory usage?
JavaScript Performance Navigation and Me.explanation: Memory column represents native memory. To get a more granular insight into the memory usage, we must type about:memory?verbose.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: When does the browser stop rendering the HTML?
options: Both Inline JavaScript block & External JavaScript file
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: When the browser parses the HTML markup, it stops rendering the HTML when it encounters an inline JavaScript block or external JavaScript file. At this point, the user experiences rendering delays.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: Which of the following handles painting the content on to the screen?
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: A rendering engine is a software that draws text and images on the screen. The rendering engine handles painting the content to the screen. When it encounters JavaScript, it hands it off to the JavaScript interpreter.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: What does the rendering engine do when it encounters JavaScript?
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: A rendering engine is a software that draws text and images on the screen. The rendering engine handles painting the content to the screen. When it encounters JavaScript, it hands it off to the JavaScript interpreter.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: Which of the following runs the JavaScript code?
options: Both Just In Time compiler and JavaScript Interpreter
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: A JavaScript engine is a computer program that executes JavaScript (JS) code. The first JS engines were mere interpreters, but all relevant modern engines utilize just-in-time compilation for improved performance. The JavaScript Interpreter runs the JavaScript code.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: Which of the following layer retrieves the content from the network?
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: The network layer is the third level of the Open Systems Interconnection Model (OSI Model) and the layer that provides data routing paths for network communication. The network layer retrieves the content from the network.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: Which of the following gets converted to DOM elements by the rendering engine?
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: The string returned by the network layer gets tokenized into meaningful chunks. The rendering engine then takes the tokens and converts them to DOM elements. There are five categories of tokens: 1) constants, 2) identifiers, 3) operators, 4) separators, and 5) reserved words.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: Which of the below does not belong to the Render Engine workflow?
options: Build DOM nodes in render tree
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation:
A rendering engine is software that draws text and images on the screen. All of the mentioned belongs to the Render Engine workflow. The Render engine workflow contains:

Parse Content
Build DOM nodes in render tree
Layout positioning of DOM elements
Paint DOM elements.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: Which is the next step after retrieving the content in chunks?
options: Build DOM nodes in render tree
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation:
After retrieving the content in chunks, the contents will be parsed. The Render engine workflow contains:

Parse Content
Build DOM nodes in render tree
Layout positioning of DOM elements
Paint DOM elements.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: What will happen after executing the script?
options: Build DOM nodes in render tree
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation:
After executing the script, the DOM nodes will be built in the render tree. The Render engine workflow contains:

Parse Content
Build DOM nodes in render tree
Layout positioning of DOM elements
Paint DOM elements.

JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.question: What would happen if there were no script tags?
options: Build DOM nodes in render tree
JavaScript Page Render BottleNecks Optim.explanation: If there were no script tags, the DOM nodes will be built in the render tree. After executing the script, the DOM nodes will be built in the render tree.

Script Loading – 1.question: What is the purpose of script loading?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The script loading loads remote JavaScript files programmatically and allow us to trick the rendering engine. The async attribute is a boolean attribute. When present, it specifies that the script will be executed asynchronously as soon as it is available.

Script Loading – 1.question: What will happen if the browser encounters a script tag without an src attribute?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: If the browser encounters a script tag without an src attribute, the rendering engine simply passes the code to the JavaScript Interpreter for execution. The src attribute specifies the location (URL) of the external resource.

Script Loading – 1.question: What is the solution to the absence of a script tag without an src attribute?
How to get a particular value using the tagged name?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The getElementsByTagName() method returns a collection of all elements in the document with the specified tag name, as a NodeList object. The method getElementsbyTagName() can be used to get a particular value using the tagged name associated with the document.

Script Loading – 1.question: What should be the type of script_url?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The type of script_url can be anything that will be compared with the typeof keyword’s result. The src attribute specifies the location (URL) of the external resource.

Script Loading – 1.question: What is the purpose of using the async attribute in the script tag?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The async option is a native attribute that will tell the browser to load the script asynchronously. The async attribute is a boolean attribute. When present, it specifies that the script will be executed asynchronously as soon as it is available.

Script Loading – 1.question: Why do we need to use an onload event in the script tag after using the async attribute?
Script Loading – 1.explanation:
When using async you don’t know when the file will be downloaded, so you can attach an onload event handler to the script tag. This will allow you to invoke or instantiate any code that will need to be run when the file is downloaded:

<script src="[URL"] async onload="init();]"></script>

Script Loading – 1.question: What is the purpose of the startTimeLogging() method?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The startTimeLogging() method captures the timing data for ad hoc, etc for referencing an uncached document.location. Once the startTimeLogging() method is called, run the code to test.

Script Loading – 1.question: What is the type of datatype the async attribute optionally accepts?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The async attribute is a boolean attribute. When present, it specifies that the script will be executed asynchronously as soon as it is available. The async attribute optionally accepts the boolean datatype of default value as true.

Script Loading – 1.question: What is the method used to create an element in the HTML DOM?
Script Loading – 1.explanation: The createElement() can be used to create an element in the HTML DOM. After the element is created, use the element.appendChild() or element.insertBefore() method to insert it to the document.

Script Loading – 2.question: What is the purpose of the method createDocumentFragment()?
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The createDocumentFragment() method creates a imaginary Node object, with all the properties and methods of the Node object. DocumentFragments are DOM Nodes. They are never part of the main DOM tree.

Script Loading – 2.question: What is the default value of the asyc attribute?
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The async attribute is a boolean attribute. When present, it specifies that the script will be executed asynchronously as soon as it is available. The async attribute optionally accepts a boolean value and by default holds the value true.

Script Loading – 2.question: What is the method to create a data frame?
Script Loading – 2.explanation: A Data frame is a two-dimensional data structure, i.e., data is aligned in a tabular fashion in rows and columns.

Script Loading – 2.question: What is the purpose of creating a data frame?
options: Hold the page render time & load time
Script Loading – 2.explanation: A Data frame is a two-dimensional data structure, i.e., data is aligned in a tabular fashion in rows and columns. You can create a data frame to hold the mean page render times for each test URL, and a data frame to hold the mean load time for each test URL.

Script Loading – 2.question: Which of the following navigator object properties is the same in both Netscape and IE?
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The property navigator.appCodeName is the same in both Netscape and IE. The appCodeName property returns the code name of the browser.

Script Loading – 2.question: Which best explains getSelection()?
options: Returns the VALUE of a selected OPTION
Returns document.URL of the window in focus
Returns the value of cursor-selected text
Returns the VALUE of a checked radio input
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The Window.getSelection() method returns a Selection object representing the range of text selected by the user or the current position of the caret. The getSelection() method returns the value of the cursor-selected text.

Script Loading – 2.question: Which of the following are client-side JavaScript object?
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The Input FileUpload object represents an HTML <input> element with type=”file”. The FileUpLoad is a client-side JavaScript object.

Script Loading – 2.question: What is the purpose of the method localeCompare()?
options: If the reference string comes before or after another string
If the reference string is validated
If the string is a reference string
If the reference string comes first
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The localeCompare() method compares two strings in the current locale. The locale is based on the language settings of the browser. The method localeCompare() returns a number indicating whether a reference string comes before or after or is the same as the given string in sort order.

Script Loading – 2.question: When the “end” event fires on EOF when no more data will arrive, which function is called?
Script Loading – 2.explanation: In computing, end-of-file (commonly abbreviated EOF) is a condition in a computer operating system where no more data can be read from a data source. The above code snippet gets “end” event fired on EOF when no more data will arrive.

Script Loading – 2.question: To define each of the set classes as a property of the sets object (namespace) for the module, the statement is ___________
Script Loading – 2.explanation: The Set object lets you store unique values of any type, whether primitive values or object references. The sets object is the namespace for the module, and we define each of the set classes as a property of this object.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: What is the purpose of lazy loading?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: Lazy loading is a design pattern commonly used in computer programming to defer initialization of an object until the point at which it is needed. It can contribute to efficiency in the program’s operation if properly and appropriately used. Lazy loading is a kind of loading in which we don’t need our JavaScript code to be available as soon as the page loads.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: Where is the external JavaScript placed in the case of lazy loading?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: Lazy loading is a kind of loading in which we don’t need our JavaScript code to be available as soon as the page loads. When we don’t need our JavaScript code to be available as soon as the page loads, we can script-load our external JavaScript after the window.onload event.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: What are the parameters of the attachEvent function?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: The addEventListener() method attaches an event handler to an element without overwriting existing event handlers. The attachEvent function accepts two parameters: the event to attach to, and the function to invoke when the event occurs.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: What is the result when the showPerformanceMetrics() is called before loading the remote script?
options: Throws an exception and It will load by itself
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: perflogger.showPerformanceMetrics() tells the user about the performance parameters of the script loading. If you try to make the call to perfLogger.showPerformanceMetrics() and the script hasn’t just loaded but also executed, then you will get an error.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: Which of the following is an attribute to the script object?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: The onload event occurs when an object has been loaded. The onload event occurs when an object has been loaded.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: Which is the method used to add an event listener?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: The addEventListener() method attaches an event handler to the specified element. The addEventListener() method is used to add an event listener to the script.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: What is the purpose of the domLoading attribute?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: domLoading is the time immediately before the user agent sets the current document readiness to ‘loading’. The domLoading attribute is used when the document begins to load.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: How is the render time calculated?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: The rendering engine parses the HTML and the CSS and displays the parsed content on the screen. The render time is calculated as Date.Now() – performance.timing.domLoading.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: The object whose properties are inherited by all instances of the class, and properties whose values are functions behaving like instance methods of the class, is _____________
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: A prototype is an object that is associated with every functions and object by default in JavaScript, where function’s prototype property is accessible and modifiable and object’s prototype property (aka attribute) is not visible. The properties of the prototype object are inherited by all instances of the class, and properties whose values are functions behave like instance methods of the class.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.question: You can refresh the webpage in JavaScript by using ___________
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 1.explanation: The reload() method is used to reload the current document.The reload() method does the same as the reload button in your browser. One can refresh the webpage in JavaScript by using location.reload.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: What is the initial step to set up a CSS Lazy Loading?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: The loading attribute allows a browser to defer loading offscreen images and iframes until users scroll near them. The CSS Lazy Loading is begun with fetching the JavaScript and the CSS files.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: What is the purpose of holding whatever tag you create in the attribute type?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: A variable is created to hold whatever tag you create, and then branch the logic based on the value of type, which identifies it’s for JavaScript or for CSS. Hence, the attribute acts as an identifier to the tag.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: What does the appendChild() method perform?
options: Appends a node in the middle of the index taken as the parameter
Appends a node as the first child
Appends a node as the last child
Replaces and appends at the last node
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: The appendChild() method appends a node as the last child of a node. You can also use this method to move an element from one element to another.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: What should be the value of the type attribute of a variable if the type of file is CSS?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: Since the type of file is CSS, the type attribute should hold the value text/css. For javascript file type attribute would hold the vale text/js.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: How to lazy load images?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: The way we would lazy load images would be to alter the HTML of the page to remove the contents of the src attribute of each image. We could just move the contents of the src attribute to an attribute in the image tag of our own design, maybe the rel attribute.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: What does the rel attribute of a variable have when the type of file is CSS?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: A web style sheet is a form of separation of presentation and content for web design in which the markup (i.e., HTML or XHTML) of a webpage contains the page’s semantic content and structure, but does not define its visual layout (style). The rel attribute must hold the value rel = ‘stylesheet’.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: What is the parameter of the method getElementsbyTagName() if we need to get an image?
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: To get the source attribute the parameter is src. The method must look like getElementsbyTageName(“img”) if we need to get an image.

JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.question: How do we stop blocking of loading and executing the perfLogger, a logging type data?
options: Placing the perfLogger before the “script” tag
Placing the perflogger after the “script” tag
JavaScript Lazy Loading – 2.explanation: A performance logging tool that provides file logging with timestamp and memory usage statistics. On calling End() a csv file of logged items will be generated. By inlining the perfLogger, we no longer block the loading and executing of it.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: What does the interpreter do when you reference variables in other scopes?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: The interpreter executes the javascript code. Normally when you reference variables in other scopes at the global level, in other namespaces, and so on—the interpreter needs to traverse the stack to get to the variable.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: The attribute location belongs to which element?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: window.location.href returns the href (URL) of the current page. The attribute location belongs to the document element.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: What will happen if you reference document.location from within an object?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: window.location.href returns the href (URL) of the current page. If you reference document.location from within an object, the interpreter will need to go from the function that references the variable, up out of the namespace to the global window scope, down to the document scope, and gets the location value.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: Why do we need to create locally scoped variables to hold value?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: window.location.assign loads a new document. The locally scoped variables are created to cache the reference to document.location.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: What is the next step after calling the startTimeLogging()?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: The startTimeLogging() method captures the timing data for ad hoc, etc for referencing an uncached document.location. Once the startTimeLogging() method is called, run the code to test.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: During the traversing through the stack, where does it go after it goes to the namespace?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: Namespace in JavaScript is nothing but a single global object which will contain all our functions, methods, variables and all that. During the traversal in the stack manner, after going to the namespace, it goes to the Window.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: During the traversing through the stack, where does it go after it goes to the window?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: window.location.assign loads a new document. During the traversal in the stack manner, after going to the window, it goes nowhere.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: During the traversing of the stack when you create a locally scoped variable, where does it go after it goes to the namespace?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: Namespace in JavaScript is nothing but a single global object which will contain all our functions, methods, variables and all that. When you create a locally scoped variable for caching the reference, the traversal reverses in the forward direction and thus, after going to the namespace, it goes to the function.

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: What is the function used to stop capturing the ad hoc timing ?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: The startTimeLogging() method captures the timing data for ad hoc, etc for referencing an uncached document.location. In order to stop capturing the ad hoc timing for referencing uncached document.location, we call the method stopTimeLogging().

Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.topic: Cache Variables and Properties across Scope
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.question: During the traversing of the stack when you create a locally scoped variable, where does it go after it goes to the location?
Cache Variables and Properties across Sc.explanation: window.location.assign loads a new document. When you create a locally scoped variable for caching the reference, the traversal reverses in the forward direction and thus, after going to the location, it goes nowhere.

Closure Compiler.question: In how many modes can the closure compiler be run?
Closure Compiler.explanation:
The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and run faster. There are totally 2 modes in which the closure compiler can be run namely:

Simple mode
Advanced mode.

Closure Compiler.question: What is the purpose of the simple mode?
Closure Compiler.explanation: The javascript minifier compresses the javascript code. In Simple mode it mostly performs like most other minifiers, removing whitespace, line breaks, and comments.

Closure Compiler.question: What is a closure compiler UI?
Closure Compiler.explanation: The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. Instead of compiling from a source language to machine code, it compiles from JavaScript to better JavaScript. A closure compiler UI is a web application.

Closure Compiler.question: What are the benefits of closure compiler?
Closure Compiler.explanation:
The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. Instead of compiling from a source language to machine code, it compiles from JavaScript to better JavaScript. The closure compiler is highly beneficial in terms of:

Efficiency: The Closure Compiler reduces the size of your JavaScript files and makes them more efficient, helping your application to load faster and reducing your bandwidth needs.
Code checking: The Closure Compiler provides warnings for illegal JavaScript and warnings for potentially dangerous operations, helping you to produce JavaScript that is less buggy and easier to maintain.

Closure Compiler.question: In what way is the closure compiler efficient?
options: Increases the size of the JavaScript files
Reduces the size of the JavaScript files
Closure Compiler.explanation: The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. The Closure Compiler reduces the size of your JavaScript files and makes them more efficient, helping your application to load faster and reducing your bandwidth needs.

Closure Compiler.question: In which way can the closure compiler can be used?
options: Only Open source and Web application
Closure Compiler.explanation:
Closure compiler parses your JavaScript, analyzes it, removes dead code and rewrites and minimizes what’s left. You can use the Closure Compiler as:

An open source Java application that you can run from the command line.
A simple web application.
A RESTful API.

Closure Compiler.question: What is the purpose of the advanced mode in the closure compiler?
Closure Compiler.explanation: In Advanced mode it rewrites the JavaScript by renaming variables and functions from longer descriptive names to single letters to save file size, and it inlines functions, coalescing them into single functions wherever it determines that it can.

Closure Compiler.question: Why is a closure template used?
options: To increase the efficiency and convenience
Dynamically generating HTML in Java and JavaScript
Closure Compiler.explanation: Instead of compiling from a source language to machine code, closure templates compiles from JavaScript to better JavaScript. Closure compiler provides with the basic facilities of removing spaces and dead code. Closure Templates are a templating system for dynamically generating HTML in both Java and JavaScript. Because the language was apparently referred to as “Soy” internal to Google, and “Soy” remains in some of the documentation and classes, sometimes Closure Templates are referred to as “Soy Templates”.

Closure Compiler.question: In what way does the closure compiler help in checking the code?
Closure Compiler.explanation: Closure compiler parses your JavaScript, analyzes it, removes dead code and rewrites and minimizes what’s left. The Closure Compiler provides warnings for illegal JavaScript and warnings for potentially dangerous operations, helping you to produce JavaScript that is less buggy and easier to maintain.

Closure Compiler.question: What is the function of the closure compiler?
options: Both Download faster and Run faster
Closure Compiler.explanation: The Closure Compiler is a tool for making JavaScript download and runs faster. It parses your JavaScript, analyzes it, removes dead code and rewrites and minimizes what’s left. It also checks syntax, variable references, and types, and warns about common JavaScript pitfalls.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Which of the following is one of the fundamental features of JavaScript?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: In computer programming, single-threading is the processing of one command at a time. One of the fundamental features of client-side JavaScript is that it is single-threaded: a browser will never run two event handlers at the same time, and it will never trigger a timer while an event handler is running.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Which of the following functions are synchronous?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: JavaScript has two synchronous load() and require(). The load() method loads data from a server and puts the returned data into the selected element.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Why shouldn’t JavaScript functions not be too long?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: When JavaScript code runs for longer than a predefined amount of time than the browser shows a message of unresponsive script. The client-side JavaScript functions must not run too long: otherwise, they will tie up the event loop and the web browser will become unresponsive to user input.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: The object that looks to the thread that creates it is _______________
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: A web worker is a JavaScript running in the background, without affecting the performance of the page. The Worker object: this is what a worker looks like from the outside to the thread that creates it.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Which of the following is a global object for a new worker?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: A web worker is a JavaScript that runs in the background, independently of other scripts, without affecting the performance of the page. The WorkerGlobalScope is the global object for a new worker, and it is what a worker thread looks like, on the inside, to itself.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Which will be invoked to create a new worker?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation:
When executing scripts in an HTML page, the page becomes unresponsive until the script is finished. To create a new worker, just use the Worker() constructor, passing a URL that specifies the JavaScript code that the worker is to run :

var loader = new Worker("utils/loader.js");

JavaScript Web Workers.question: What will happen if you specify an absolute URL in the Worker constructor?
options: Must not have the same origin
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: If you specify an absolute URL, it must have the same origin (same protocol, host, and port) as that containing document. In Firefox, if you want to use workers in extensions and would like to have access to js-ctypes, you should use the ChromeWorker object instead.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: How can you send data using a Worker object?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation:
Once you have a Worker object, you can send data to it with postMessage(). The value you pass to postMessage() will be cloned, and the resulting copy will be delivered to the worker via a message event. postMessage() sends a message — which can consist of any JavaScript object — to the worker’s inner scope.

loader.postMessage("file.txt");

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Which property is used to manage multiple event handlers?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: message event is fired when the worker’s parent receives a message from its worker which is also available via the onmessage property. You can use onmessage and onerror properties if you want to manage multiple event handlers.

JavaScript Web Workers.question: Which is the function that allows a worker to terminate itself?
JavaScript Web Workers.explanation: Worker.terminate() Immediately terminates the worker. This does not offer the worker an opportunity to finish its operations. The close() function allows a worker to terminate itself, and it is similar in effect to the terminate() method of a Worker object.

JavaScript Blobs.question: BLOB stands for ______________
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: A Blob is an opaque reference to, or handle for, a chunk of data. The name comes from SQL databases, where it means “Binary Large Object.” In JavaScript, Blobs often represent binary data, and they can be large, but neither is required: a Blob could also represent the contents of a small text file.

JavaScript Blobs.question: The size of blobs are generally calculated in ____________
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. Blobs are opaque all you can do with them directly is determine their size in bytes, ask for their MIME type, and chop them up into smaller Blobs.

JavaScript Blobs.question: The blobs are generally stored in ____________
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. The web browser can store Blobs in memory or on disk, and Blobs can represent really enormous chunks of data (such as video files) that are too large to fit in main memory without first being broken into smaller pieces with slice().

JavaScript Blobs.question: The blobs are broken into smaller pieces using which of the following functions?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: The File interface is based on Blob, inheriting blob functionality and expanding it to support files on the user’s system. The web browser can store Blobs in memory or on disk, and Blobs can represent really enormous chunks of data (such as video files) that are too large to fit in main memory without first being broken into smaller pieces with slice().

JavaScript Blobs.question: Which algorithm supports blobs?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. Blobs are supported by the structured clone algorithm, which means that you can obtain one from another window or thread via the message event.

JavaScript Blobs.question: Which database can be used to retrieve blobs?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: A Blob object represents a file-like object of immutable, raw data. Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. Blobs can be retrieved from client-side databases.

JavaScript Blobs.question: Which object can be used to create your own blobs?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: Blobs represent data that isn’t necessarily in a JavaScript-native format. You can create your own blobs, using a BlobBuilder object to build them out of strings, ArrayBuffer objects, and other Blobs.

JavaScript Blobs.question: Which of the following is a subtype of Blob?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: The File interface is based on Blob, inheriting blob functionality and expanding it to support files on the user’s system. The client-side JavaScript File object is a subtype of Blob: a File is just a Blob of data with a name and a modification date.

JavaScript Blobs.question: Which method facilitates in uploading a Blob to a server?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: The Blob() constructor allows one to create blobs from other objects. You can upload a Blob to a server by passing it to the send() method of an XMLHttpRequest object.

JavaScript Blobs.question: A Blob URL can be created using which of the following function?
JavaScript Blobs.explanation: The Blob() constructor allows one to create blobs from other objects. Create a Blob URL with the function createObjectURL(). At the time of this writing, the draft specification and Firefox 4 put this function in a global object named URL, and Chrome and Webkit prefix that new global, calling it webkitURL.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: Where are memory leaks found?
options: Both Client side and Server side objects
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: Memory leaks happen when your code needs to consume memory in your application, which should be released after a given task is completed but isn’t. Memory leaks occur when we are developing client-side reusable scripting objects.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: Which handler is triggered when the content of the document in the window is stable and ready for manipulation?
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: One of the most important event handlers is the onload handler of the Window object. It is triggered when the content of the document displayed in the window is stable and ready to be manipulated. JavaScript code is commonly wrapped within an onload event handler.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: What is the central concept of JavaScript memory management?
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation:
The central concept of JavaScript memory management is a concept of reachability. The main cause for leaks in garbage collected languages are unwanted references.

A distinguished set of objects are assumed to be reachable: these are known as the roots. Typically, these include all the objects referenced from anywhere in the call stack (that is, all local variables and parameters in the functions currently being invoked), and any global variables.
Objects are kept in memory while they are accessible from roots through a reference or a chain of references.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: When does a memory leak happen?
options: Browser doesn’t release memory from objects unnecessary
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: Memory leaks happen when your code needs to consume memory in your application, which should be released after a given task is complete but isn’t. Memory leak happens when the browser for some reason doesn’t release memory from objects which are not needed any more.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: What will happen when the data of the jQuery.cache is read from an element?
options: Unique number is retrieved as elem[jQuery.expando]
Unique number is retrieved as elem[jQuery.expando] & Data is read from jQuery.cache[id]
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation:
jQuery.cache[id] is used to associate handlers and other data with elements. When the data is read from an element:

The element unique number is retrieved from id = elem[ jQuery.expando].
The data is read from jQuery.cache[id].

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: The style property belongs to which of the following object?
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: Each Element object has style and className properties that allow scripts to specify CSS styles for a document element or to alter the CSS class names that apply to the element.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: Which of the following functions are referenced internally?
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: setTimeout(function, milliseconds) executes a function, after waiting a specified number of milliseconds. Functions used in setTimeout/setInterval are referenced internally and tracked until complete, then cleaned up.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: What is the purpose of destroying the functions and objects?
options: Prevent the dropping of reference count to 0
Centralize the responsibility to clean up
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation:
The primary purpose of a destroy function is to centralize the responsibility for cleaning up anything that the object has done that will:

Prevent its reference count from dropping to 0 (for example, removing problematic event listeners and callbacks and unregistering from any services).
Consume unnecessary CPU cycles, such as intervals or animations.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: When does a cycle occur during memory leak?
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: Old versions of Internet Explorer could not detect cyclic references between DOM nodes and JavaScript code. A cycle happens when two objects reference each other in such a way that both objects retain each other.

JavaScript and Memory Leak.question: Which of the following is a way to retain an object in memory?
JavaScript and Memory Leak.explanation: Any object inside the timer will hold a reference in order to run that piece of code somewhere in the future without any problems. One particularly obscure way to retain an object in memory is to log it to the console.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: In which format does JavaScript support external JavaScript?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: JavaScript supports external JavaScript, in the form of .js file. This extension can be captured by a number of applications including: Windows Script Host, Dreamweaver MX, Notepad, Netscape Navigator, PavScrip, UltraEdit. The files are generally text files.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: What are the two parts of JavaScript libraries?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation:
All JavaScript libraries consists of two parts:

The external JavaScript itself, which is simply a text file with the containing JavaScript code, saved as a .js file.
A “script” tag referencing the external JavaScript file and defined on the page(s) that uses the library.

The <script> element either contains scripting statements, or it points to an external script file through the src attribute.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: Which of the following is added to prefs.js when the console is automatically opened during JavaScript error?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation:
The prefs.js file, located in the profile folder, is used by Firefox and other Mozilla-based applications to store settings. For instance, when you create a new e-mail account in Thunderbird, the account name and server settings will be stored in the prefs.js file in your Thunderbird profile folder.
The code :

user_pref("javascript.console.open_on_error", true);

is added to prefs.js when the console is automatically opened during JavaScript error.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: Which of the following is possible to be referenced in external JavaScript?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: PHP (recursive acronym for PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor) is a widely-used open source general-purpose scripting language that is especially suited for web development and can be embedded into HTML. One of the lesser known sides of external JavaScript is the ability to reference a PHP file instead of the familiar .js file.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: Which of the following attribute takes the source of the PHP file?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation:
Php file is used an scripting language for backend development. The syntax to referencing a PHP file using external JavaScript is consistent enough with what we already know:

<script type="text/javascript" src="myscript.php"></script>

External JavaScript and PHP.question: What kind of path can the PHP file be?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: The PHP code is enclosed in special start and end processing instructions <?php and ?> that allows you to jump into and out of “PHP mode”. The PHP file is either an absolute or relative path to a PHP script instead of the usual .js file.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: Which of the following global variables is used to get parameters?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: The global variable $HTTP_GET_VARS[] is used to get parameters. $HTTP_GET_VARS contains the same initial information, but is not a superglobal.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: What is the purpose of the RegExp method test()?
options: Tests for a match in its float parameter
Tests for a match in its string parameter
Tests for a match in its integer parameter
Test for a match in node
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: RegExp stands for regular expression which is an object that describes a pattern of characters.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: What is the purpose of the function parameter filetype?
options: File type that should not be got
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: The File.type property is an inbuilt function of File WebAPI which gives the media type (MIME) of the file represented by a file object. The function parameter “filetype” lets you tell the script what file type to expect before loading.

External JavaScript and PHP.question: Which of the following is the method used to add an element to the desired location?
External JavaScript and PHP.explanation: The method element.appendChild() is used to add the element to the desired location within the document tree. The appendChild() method appends a node as the last child of a node.

HTML APIs.question: Which program code doesn’t need preprocessing before being run?
HTML APIs.explanation: A scripting or script language is a programming language for a special run-time environment that automates the execution of tasks. A script is program code that doesn’t need pre-processing (e.g. compiling) before being run.

HTML APIs.question: What is the significance of scripting?
HTML APIs.explanation: Scripting languages are often interpreted (rather than compiled). Scripting makes Web pages more dynamic) For example, without reloading a new version of a page it may allow modifications to the content of that page, or allow content to be added to or sent from that page. The former has been called DHTML (Dynamic HTML), and the latter AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML).

HTML APIs.question: What is the purpose of XMLHttpRequest?
options: Load content by loading new document
Load content without loading new document
HTML APIs.explanation: The XMLHttpRequest object can be used to request data from a web server. XMLHttpRequest makes it possible to load additional content from the Web without loading a new document, a core component of AJAX.

HTML APIs.question: Which API makes the user’s current location available to browser-based application?
HTML APIs.explanation: The Geolocation API allows the user to provide their location to web applications if they so desire. For privacy reasons, the user is asked for permission to report location information.

HTML APIs.question: Which of the following ensures additional interactivity mechanism?
HTML APIs.explanation: Web Accessibility Initiative – Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA) is a technical specification published by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) that specifies how to increase the accessibility of web pages, in particular, dynamic content, and user interface components developed with Ajax, HTML, JavaScript, and related technologies. WAI ARIA offers mechanisms to ensure that this additional interactivity remains usable independent of devices and disabilities.

HTML APIs.question: What is the necessity to have API?
options: Both performing activities and Describe particular task
HTML APIs.explanation: In computer programming, an application programming interface is a set of subroutine definitions, communication protocols, and tools for building software. An API may describe the ways in which a particular task is performed.

HTML APIs.question: What is the purpose of the event onAirEvent?
options: Both Content is played and transferred
HTML APIs.explanation: The event onAirEvent is fired when the player starts playing content being broadcasted on the channel. The method is called at the time of the creation of adspace.

HTML APIs.question: What is the purpose of the event disconnectionEvent?
HTML APIs.explanation: navigator.onLine is a property that maintains a true/false value (true for online, false for offline). This property is updated whenever the user switches into “Offline Mode”. The event disconnectionEvent is fired when the player disconnects from the channel, whether a result of user interaction or not.

HTML APIs.question: When does one use the event ready?
HTML APIs.explanation: The ready event occurs when the DOM (document object model) has been loaded. It is safe to interact with it after this event fired.

HTML APIs.question: When does one use the method startOverlays()?
HTML APIs.explanation: A new ad request is made every time when the method startOverlays() gets called. It is used at the time of creation of the ad.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: What is the reason for avoiding the attributes property in the HTML DOM?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: When a web page is loaded, the browser creates a Document Object Model of the page. The reason for avoiding the attributes property in the HTML DOM is because Attributes don’t have attributes.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: What is the purpose of the method nodeMap.setNamedItem()?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: The setNamedItem() method adds the specified node to the NamedNodeMap. The method nodeMap.setNamedItem() sets the specified attribute node (by name).

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: How is everything treated in HTML DOM?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation:
The HTML DOM model is constructed as a tree of Objects. In the HTML DOM (Document Object Model), everything is a node:

The document itself is a document node.
All HTML elements are element nodes.
All HTML attributes are attribute nodes.
Text inside HTML elements are text nodes.
Comments are comment nodes.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: What does the NamedNodeMap object represent in the HTML DOM?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: In the HTML DOM, the NamedNodeMap object represents an unordered collection of an elements attribute nodes. The nodes in the NamedNodeMap can be accessed through their name.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: What is the purpose of the Attr object in the HTML DOM?
options: Used to focus on a particular part of the HTML page
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: When a web page is loaded, the browser creates a Document Object Model of the page. In the HTML DOM, the Attr object represents an HTML attribute.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: What is the work of the form control elements in the HTML DOM?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: Form control elements: The form object contains all the elements defined for that object such as text fields, buttons, radio buttons, and checkboxes. The elements collection returns a collection of all elements in a form.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: How are the objects organized in the HTML DOM?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: The HTML DOM model is constructed as a tree of Objects. The objects are organized in the hierarchy format in the HTML DOM.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: Which of the following is a type of HTML DOM?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: IE4 document object model was introduced in Version 4 of Microsoft’s Internet Explorer browser. IE 5 and later versions include support for most basic W3C DOM features. All of the above mentioned are types of HTML DOM.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: What is the purpose of the Legacy DOM?
options: Allows access to few keys and elements
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: The Legacy DOM: This is the model which was introduced in early versions of JavaScript language. It is well supported by all browsers but allows access only to certain key portions of documents, such as forms, form elements, and images.

JavaScript HTML DOM.question: Which object is the top of the hierarchy?
JavaScript HTML DOM.explanation: The DOM is arranged in the form of tree with every node as an object. Window object is the top of the hierarchy. It is the outmost element of the object hierarchy.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which of the following can be implemented using animation?
JavaScript Animation.explanation:
JavaScript animations are done by programming gradual changes in an element’s style. You can use JavaScript to create a complex animation which includes but not limited to:

Fireworks
Fade Effect
Roll-in or Roll-out
Page-in or Page-out
Object movements.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which is the function that calls another function after a time interval?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The setTimeout(function, duration) calls function after duration milliseconds from now. setInterval(function, milliseconds) is same as setTimeout(), but repeats the execution of the function continuously.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which function is used to clear the timer value?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The clearTimeout() method clears a timer set with the setTimeout() method. The ID value returned by setTimeout() is used as the parameter for the clearTimeout() method.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which is the property used to position the object in the left of the screen?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The property object.style.left = distance in pixels or points sets distance from left edge of the screen. This property specifies the left position of the element including padding, scrollbar, border and margin. Whereas the setTimeout(function, duration) calls function after duration milliseconds from now.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which is the function used to call a function in every time duration?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The setInterval(function, duration) calls function after every duration milliseconds.

JavaScript Animation.question: How do we get the DOM object in JavaScript?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The getElementbyId() is used to get the DOM object in JavaScript by simply calling that function associated with the HTML document. The object in this method gets referenced by the id name.

JavaScript Animation.question: How to assign the image source in JavaScript?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: For accesing any image in webpage its address or url is specified. The image source is defined as image.src = “/images/html.gif”.

JavaScript Animation.question: How do we create and preload an image object in JavaScript?
options: Both Use new keyword and Call Image()
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The Image() constructor creates and preloads a new image object. The url is specified and the image is preloaded.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which event handler is triggered when the user’s mouse moves onto a link?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The onmouseover attribute fires when the mouse pointer moves over an element. The onmouseover attribute is often used together with the onmouseout attribute.

JavaScript Animation.question: Which event handler is triggered when the user’s mouse moves away from a link?
JavaScript Animation.explanation: The onMouseOut event handler is triggered when the user’s mouse moves away from the link. It is often used together with onMouseOver attribute.

JavaScript Validation.question: In which part does the form validation occur?
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The data information from the client side is first sent to the server side. Form validation used to occur at the server after the client had entered all necessary data and then pressed the Submit button.

JavaScript Validation.question: What would happen if the data in the client had been wrong?
options: Sends back the data and Waits for correction
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The only way to obtain data is from the server side which is used to perform further operations on the data. If some of the data that had been entered by the client had been in the wrong form or was simply missing, the server would have to send all the data back to the client and request that the form is resubmitted with correct information.

JavaScript Validation.question: What is the purpose of the basic validation?
options: Both Data correctness and Mere data existence
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The data entered through the server side is used for validation. First of all, the form must be checked to make sure data was entered into each form field that required it. This would need just loop through each field in the form and check for data.

JavaScript Validation.question: What is the purpose of data format validation?
options: Both Data correctness and Mere data existence
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The data entered through the server side is used for validation. The data that is entered must be checked for correct form and value. This would need to put more logic to test the correctness of data.

JavaScript Validation.question: Which is the function that is called to validate a data?
options: no predefined function for data validation
JavaScript Validation.explanation: There is no such function to validate a data but, you can write a function with any name to validate the data. Hence there is no predefined function for data validation.

JavaScript Validation.question: How to find the index of a particular string?
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The indexOf() function can be used to find out the index of a particular character or a string. This method return an integer telling the address of the particular character.

JavaScript Validation.question: How do you focus a particular part of the HTML page in JavaScript?
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The focus() function can be used to focus a particular part of the HTML page in JavaScript. It sets the element as the active element in the current document. It can be applied to one html element at a single time in a current document.

JavaScript Validation.question: Which of the following is the child object of the JavaScript navigator?
JavaScript Validation.explanation: The JavaScript navigator object is used for browser detection. The JavaScript navigator object includes a child object called plugins.

JavaScript Validation.question: Which of the following is not the properties of a plug-in entry?
JavaScript Validation.explanation:
Plugins are reusable portions of code which help you write even less Javascript to achieve specific features on the client side. Each plug-in has an entry in the array. Each entry has the following properties:

name – is the name of the plug-in.
filename – is the executable file that was loaded to install the plug-in.
description – is a description of the plug-in, supplied by the developer.
mimeTypes – is an array with one entry for each MIME type supported by the plug-in.

JavaScript Validation.question: What is the purpose of the mimeTypes property of a plug-in entry?
JavaScript Validation.explanation: MIME stands for Multi-purpose Internet Mail Extensions. mimeTypes is an array with one entry for each MIME type supported by the plug-in.

Image Map.question: Which side of the image map can be created using JavaScript?
Image Map.explanation: Javascript is used for the creation of client side data. You can use JavaScript to create client side image map.

Image Map.question: Which is the attribute used to enable the Client-side image map?
Image Map.explanation: The usemap attribute is associated with a element’s name or id attribute, and creates a relationship between the and the .

Image Map.question: Which are the special tags used for image mapping?
Image Map.explanation: The usemap attribute specifies an image (or an object) as an image-map (an image-map is an image with clickable areas). The special tags used for image mapping are map and area.

Image Map.question: Which is the element that follows the use of “img”?
options: any element can follow the use of “img”
Image Map.explanation: The usemap attribute is associated with a element’s name or id attribute, and creates a relationship between the and the . The “map” element actually creates the map for the image and usually follows directly after the “img ” element.

Image Map.question: What is the purpose of the area element?
options: Shape and coordinates of the hotspot
Shape and area of the hotspot
Image Map.explanation: The <area> tag defines an area inside an image-map (an image-map is an image with clickable areas). The <area> element is always nested inside a <map> tag. The area element specifies the shape and the coordinates that define the boundaries of each clickable hotspot.

Image Map.question: Which of the following is not a navigator property?
Image Map.explanation: The navigator object contains information about the browser. All of the above mentioned are the properties of a navigator.

Image Map.question: What is the purpose of the platform[] property in a navigator?
options: Platform where the image map was designed
Platform where the browser was compiled
Platform where the plugin was designed
Image Map.explanation: The platform[] property is a string that contains the platform for which the browser was compiled. “Win32” for 32-bit Windows operating systems.

Image Map.question: What is the purpose of the preference method in a navigator?
Image Map.explanation: The preference(name,value) method allows a signed script to get and set some Netscape preferences. If the second parameter is omitted, this method will return the value of the specified preference; otherwise, it sets the value Netscape only.

Image Map.question: Which of the following is not a navigator method?
